Thus, in compounding the elixir, one cannot do without the blossom and sprout as the root. For anointing the crucible, covering and sealing its edges, and other methods, if even one step is missing, it will not succeed.

Water is the pivot of the Dao, and its number is named One. As lead and mercury both belong to the northern Water phase, the number of Water is One—this means Heavenly One generates Water. Moreover, the Dao generates the One, and the One is the beginning of the Five Phases, the pivot and mechanism of the Dao. Thus, one catty each of lead and mercury is used. According to this scripture, using one catty of mercury accords with Heaven’s measure and the numbers of the *Book of Changes*; this is the Yin Prime Elixir, with one catty as one dose. If one catty of cinnabar is used, with yellow lead as the covering base, it is called the Yang Prime Elixir. For an elixir of pure Yang transformation, yellow sprout is used. Otherwise, one *liang* of golden blossom serves as the foundation, added month by month, totaling thirty catties after nine months—this is also called the Special Nine Cycles Method. Thus, the methods of Returning Elixir number several schools; though their transformations differ, their crafting follows the same principle. Those who grasp the reason, all produce the Great Elixir. Yet only when fire is mastered does it become the supreme immortal medicine.

At the beginning of Yin and Yang, the Mysterious contains the yellow sprout. As lead belongs to Water, it is called "Mysterious." Within raw lead lies the yellow sprout, resembling gold in form—hence the name "yellow sprout." Lead is the master of the Five Metals and the northern River Chariot. Thus, lead is black on the outside but harbors golden blossom within. Yin is Metal Elder, and Yang is mercury. The Five Metals refer to lead, also called Metal Elder. Metal Elder is another name for lead. Since lead contains the five colors within, it produces five-colored gold—hence the name "Five Metals." It governs mercury, belongs to Water, and can carry the elixir boat. Like a chariot, it is called the River Chariot. As it holds gold within, it harbors the golden blossom. When transformed by yellow lead, it congeals like a mirror, and when struck, resembles horse’s teeth—thus called yellow sprout. If one values the yellow sprout, one must first refine raw lead to obtain its golden blossom and yellow sprout, though both emerge from lead, their crafting differs.

For golden blossom: take nine-cycled lead, remove impurities, and refine it until it resembles a mirror. For one catty of lead, add four *liang* of mercury—some say two *liang*. The teachings vary: some advocate equal parts, others a four-six ratio. Most are incorrect; only three or four parts are precious. Thus, the ancients kept this secret: when adding mercury, swiftly apply fire for half a day, and the golden blossom will emerge like mica, displaying the five colors of mysterious yellow. Use an iron ladle to gather it. If the golden blossom’s color remains unchanged like gold, it is mercury blossom. If, after congealing, its color shifts to greenish, the green is lead blossom. Such blossom is unfit, and no blossom will emerge. Where there is mercury, there is blossom; when the blossom is exhausted, add more mercury until sufficient, then stop. Some say nine-cycled lead is unnecessary—this is mostly incorrect. Otherwise, at least three cycles are needed to produce blossom.

According to this *Contract*, take one catty of blossom, melt it into liquid, add one catty of mercury to congeal it, then grind it into powder and place it in the crucible. For a pure Yang elixir, mix the blossom with lead sand and seal it for one hundred days until the blossom turns red and brown. For one *liang* of blossom, add one *liang* of raw mercury, grind them into powder, and place in the crucible. The sealed blossom is called Autumn Stone or Standing Control Stone. If crafting the Special Method, apply the blossom to coat the crucible and add raw mercury without limit—this too can form the elixir. For yellow sprout: take one catty of capital lead, add four *liang* of mercury, and place in a Shouzhou porcelain bowl. Apply intense fire to melt it into a mirror-like liquid, then cool the bowl until it congeals into a golden color, resembling horse’s teeth when struck. Its use is like that of golden blossom. Other teachings are mostly erroneous. The sealed blossom and sprout must be placed in lead sand.

The method of refining gold through nine cycles involves frying lead into sand and smelting sand back into lead—repeating this nine times is called the Nine Lead Method, which cannot be fully expounded here.

"Mysterious containing" refers to mercury as the Mysterious, and the lead blossom as the contained. The blossom is the yellow sprout—hence "Mysterious containing yellow sprout." "Clad in coarse cloth yet harboring jade" describes one who appears as a madman. Lead’s exterior is black with a yellow hue, like coarse cloth. "Harboring jade" refers to its inner whiteness. Like a madman clad in coarse cloth, lead’s whiteness resembles jade—hence the "madman."

Gold is the mother of Water, and the mother conceals the child’s embryo. Gold here is silver, and Water is lead. Lead contains silver, making it the mother of lead; lead is the child of silver, thus concealing the child’s embryo. Water is the child of gold, and the child resides in the mother’s womb. The mother is silver, and Water is lead; silver is the child, thus dwelling in the mother’s womb. Therefore, silver is the fine matchmaker of the Seven Treasures and the marrow of Yin and Yang.

The scripture states: "Do not ruin my lead, nor abandon my life-metal. Do not break my chariot, nor forsake my return home." It also says: "If the lead is not true, mercury will be hard to befriend. If the lead is genuine, the household retainer will not be lost." The Green-Waisted Envoy and the Red-Blood General unite the two families, gathering different clans into one flock. Thus, the Great Elixir cannot be formed without lead.

When using lead, one must obtain refined, salty lead. If it is white and greasy, it can yield blossom and sprout. If it is spent, it will be pale and yield no blossom. "Mysterious lead with a green waist" refers to malachite. The "Red-Blood General" is realgar. One is mercury, the other is golden blossom. *Commentary on the Zhouyi Cantong Qi*, Volume One, concludes.

*Commentary on the Zhouyi Cantong Qi*, Scroll Three (Anonymous)

The Perfected One attains the utmost subtlety, now present, now absent. The absence is yang lead; the presence is yin mercury. Moreover, silver pertains to the yang treasure, while the Perfected One is the Supreme Treasure Person. Knowing that within lead lies the treasure, one transforms mercury into the elixir.

The great abyss billows in mist, now sinking, now floating. Advancing, it #1 spreads and disperses, each guarding its own boundary. The great abyss refers to molten lead turned to liquid, into which mercury is cast. Now sinking, now floating—this is the method of forming golden flowers: mercury enters the lead liquid, dispersing within the lead, thus bound by the lead and unable to escape its confines. Hence, one knows that to compound the elixir, one must first refine lead into flowers to subdue mercury.

Another interpretation of the great abyss refers to the ash pool where lead yields silver. Thus, the scripture states: "In the ash pool, with blazing heat, lead sinks and silver floats. Pure white, the treasure appears, capable of forging yellow gold." Both meanings are valid.

Gathered, it resembles white; wrought, it turns vermilion. Lead serves as #2 the outer guard, silk enveloping #3 the steadfast core. This speaks of molten lead, white in its liquid state, which, when mercury is introduced and worked, changes color to crimson. Lead acts as the outer guard like silk, enclosing the refined mercury within, preventing its flight. Thus, it remains steadfast and abides, white guarding black.

Here concludes the discussion of forming flower buds; what follows concerns the entry into the crucible.

Round or square, a *cun* in diameter, they merge and support one another. Born before Heaven and Earth. *Born* here means intermingled. It refers to mercury entering the lead flowers, blending and supporting one another, later to be placed within the Mysterious White Metal Flower Crucible. Mercury is the essence of metal, one *cun* in diameter and round, weighing one *jin*—the measure used in the *Cantong Qi*. *Before* refers to the crucible. The upper lid is Heaven; the lower lid, Earth. Thus, once Heaven and Earth are established, the myriad things are born. Within the cosmos, nothing exists that is not nurtured by Heaven and Earth. The Dao gives birth to Heaven and Earth, and the elixir belongs to the Dao. Therefore, it must be nurtured by Heaven and Earth, which is why the crucible is discussed first to cultivate the great elixir.

Lofty and revered. The crucible rests within the Supreme One’s furnace, atop the Three Terraces, uniquely exalted—thus, lofty and revered. The virtue of the Dao is likewise exalted and revered, hence the elixir’s path is supremely noble and high.

Surrounding it are #4 walls and gates. The walls are the Supreme One’s furnace. The furnace has four sides, #5 each opening into eight gates to channel the eight winds. It holds twelve protrusions symbolizing the twelve hours, twelve cavities symbolizing the twelve earthly branches, and four tiers corresponding to the four seasons—hence, walls and gates.

Its form resembles Penglai’s gourd. The *gourd* is the crucible, also akin to a *touhu* vase, shaped like a crucible in various styles. Some resemble melons, others are square or edged, each with its purpose. A small, elongated handle is used for dipping water and weighing. If refining fire for yellow and white, a silver crucible is employed. The reed tube is two *cun* in diameter, one and a half *cun* long, holding one *jin* of mercury. *Penglai* refers to the furnace, modeled after the Five Peaks, resembling Mount Penglai.

Encircling it, #6 sealed and bound, the four passages are secured. *Encircling* refers to the crucible’s four—or two—handles. The lower seal confines the mercury within, preventing its escape. Guarding it, tightly sealed. #7 *Sealed* refers to the sealed boundary; *guarding* refers to tending the fire. One must not slacken by day, for a breach in the seal is most urgent. If the seal is not firm and tight, the medicine will entirely escape. If the seal is secure and dense, only the essence remains, leaving only lead elixir. If the silver crucible is not carefully sealed, only the elixir remains while the mercury flees entirely.

The scripture states: "Six-and-one" refers to six parts to one, making seven measures, the sealed boundary like lacquer, not the seven kinds of clay. Such as the eight stones, four spirits, golden blossom, jade powder, and the like. For the elixir, *yushi* powder and *chishizhi* are used for the upper and lower layers, with ash salt. For this elixir, only golden flowers and yellow buds suffice. Otherwise, lead and cinnabar are finely ground and fermented like mud, applied atop salt ash. For silver crucibles and reed tubes, use *dapeng* cinnabar mixed with refined silver powder and steel sand. Other texts mention non-ash, wood, *rong* salt, and the like—these are incorrect.

Seal against deceit and deviation. This means the sealed boundary must be firm and tight, so there shall be no loss or deficiency. "Deviation" refers to flying away and loss. The winding chambers connect in sequence, to guard against the unforeseen. "Unforeseen" means loss. It speaks of interlocking male and female parts, fitting together like dog’s teeth. Externally, an elephant’s trunk is applied. Stir deeply and exhort earnestly—firmness and tightness are paramount. This may be contemplated with profound thought, but not with anxious toil.

When the *qi* of spirit fills the chamber, none can retain it. Those who preserve it prosper; those who lose it perish. "Spirit *qi*" is fire. "Chamber" is the furnace. "Fills" means the martial fire is abundant. If the fire is too strong, the mercury’s power cannot withstand it. Nothing is more slippery and swift than mercury—once gone, it leaves no trace, and no place can be found to seek it. Thus, the boundary must be as firm and tight as lacquer.

If the crucible is pierced or damaged, one must grasp the fire’s nature across the four seasons, balancing civil and martial fires in due time—this is why profound contemplation is unnecessary. When present, it flourishes; when perfected, it becomes the elixir; when lost, it vanishes. Before attempting to refine and sublimate, first refine the crucible and vessel, then ensure the sealed boundary is secure. When fire and *qi* are harmonized, and one’s diligence is unwavering, how could there be loss or failure?

Movement and stillness, rest and activity—these ever accompany the practitioner. This speaks of repeatedly handling the crucible and managing the fire, which must always be overseen by three people. Thus, when yang moves and yin is still, or when advancing and retreating, one must not leave the furnace. Even when movement occurs, there is no true rest—hence, it ever accompanies the practitioner.

This is not the method of traversing the hidden treasuries; it is inner contemplation with focused thought. "Traversing" means to pass through. It speaks of managing the fire and moving *qi*, all in accordance with the methods of the stellar lodges and hidden treasuries. Moreover, the chamber must be purified: expel ghosts by burning, inscribe the nine furnaces, draw the true forms of the Five Peaks, the true scripts of the eight directions, the Jade Maidens and Heavenly Lads, the Eight Lords and Nine Perfected, the Twelve Divine Kings, and the Three Great Generals. Step the void altar in the eight directions, hang mirrors on all sides, plant swords at the four quarters, burn incense, and maintain purity and precepts. Concentrate the mind to constantly visualize the Most High, the Nine Perfected, Eight Sages, Jade Maidens, Immortal Lads, Heavenly Soldiers, and Mighty Warriors. To the left and right, the Green Dragon and White Tiger; before and behind, the Vermilion Bird and Dark Warrior—all within a single chamber.

If one grasps the wondrous principle of the elixir, one need not draw these images. Some set up a Supreme Unity furnace, merely purifying the mind and visualizing the host of sages—this too suffices for the furnace’s work.

Tread the steps of the Dipper’s lodges. This means that when first igniting the fire in the altar chamber, or when thunder, rain, evil winds, and the like arise, one must perform the Yu Step. Step the stars of the Dipper—three steps, nine traces. The six jia days follow the sequence of days and hours. All major operations follow the twelve earthly branches in order, cycling through the sixty jia-zi. From the primordial to this point, the discussion of crucibles, sealed boundaries, fire management, and methods of operation is reiterated thrice—this is to urge the practitioner to be meticulous.

At first, the method is civil; later, martial—gradually nurturing the fire ensures nothing is lost. The Way of yin suppresses one and nine, its turbid chaos playing with the primordial womb. "The Way of yin" refers to the yin primordial method. "One" is the essence of lead, belonging to the northern Kan water, whose number is one. "Nine" is mercury. Mercury is born of cinnabar, belonging to the southern Li fire, whose number is nine. Melt the essence of lead into water, then cast it into the refined mercury to blend them. The chaotic mercury is pressed into the lead, which then conceals the mercury within itself, like a child dwelling in the womb, unable to flee. Enveloped by the lead’s womb, it moves up and down—hence, it is said to "play with the womb."

Consuming *qi*, the intestines and stomach resound; exhaling the true, inhaling the deviant. "Deviant" is lead; "true" is mercury; "*qi*" is fire. It speaks of mercury uniting with fire *qi* to become one body. Thus, the dragon exhales and the tiger inhales—this refers to the breathing of dragon and tiger. Mercury within lead causes the head to resound in the intestines and stomach. After the sun is full, the mercury is exhaled onto the lead, taking the form of cinnabar, its color crimson-purple—this is called the True Yang Elixir. The common analogy is that one exhales the dead and inhales the living.

Day and night, one does not sleep; the yang brightness never rests. "Yang brightness" is fire. It speaks of the fire within a year, extending up to three years, never ceasing day or night. The common analogy is that one practices *qi*-absorption day and night without rest.

The body grows weary, the spirit dazed, as if in a stupor. It speaks of mercury within the lead’s blossoming sap, subjected to day and night of fire—its state is dazed, as if in a stupor. It also analogizes the practitioner tending the furnace fire day and night without rest, becoming exhausted, the spirit and emotions dazed as if in a stupor.

Furthermore, in making the elixir or yellow and white, one must first refine mercury into cinnabar. For the elixir, use three years of left-flavored [mercury] mixed with golden blossoms and branches, also placed in silver vessels to branch. Continuously scrape the dry mercury from the four sides. For yellow and white, use equal parts mother [lead] to branch the mercury into cinnabar, like stone. Place the cinnabar in the vessel, subdue the fire for one hundred twenty days to make a treasure. If unfit for use as medicine, it is because of the presence of metallic lead.

For the nine-cycle elixir, branch the mercury into cinnabar, grind it finely, place it in the crucible, and cover it with the Five Talismans. The correct discussion of this scripture is as above. When gold and mercury enter the crucible, the common analogy is that absorbing *qi* severs the root—spirit and essence grow dazed, the body weary and stuporous.

The hundred vessels boil and surge, unable to settle in clarity. It speaks of mercury within lead, in the crucible under fire’s pressure, constantly surging and boiling. The mercury rushes into the lead, unable to settle in clarity within the hundred vessels. The common analogy is that from consuming *qi* to this point, when *qi* reaches the cinnabar field and fills it, the hundred vessels constantly roar like thunder, like boiling water—yet even after a long time, one cannot attain longevity.

Vain movement and weariness prevent the elixir from being ingested. If the spirit is as if in a stupor, there is ultimately no principle of eternal life.

Pile earth to erect an altar, morning and evening offer reverent sacrifices. It speaks of erecting an altar within the elixir courtyard, offering sacrifices morning and evening. The common analogy is that one seeking the Dao erects an altar, toiling diligently in sacrifice—yet still cannot attain the Dao.

Ghostly beings manifest forms, dreams and sleep stir emotions.

The adept diligently tends the furnace flame, ever with concentrated mind, and so gains the protection of spirits and gods, who in nightly dreams divinely instruct the mercury. The common analogy is that one who erects an altar and offers sacrifices may likewise be moved by spirits appearing in dreams—yet this is called attaining the Dao.

Heart gladdened, will rejoicing, one deems it certain to prolong the term. *Term* here means the span of years. For the toil of body and mind gains the aid of spirits, and the heart’s intent rejoices. Once the divine elixir is formed, its ingestion surely extends years without death. The common analogy is that one moved by spirits appearing in dreams feels joy in the heart and speaks of attaining longevity. Yet suddenly the mandate of heaven is cut short, and the body decays, exposed to the elements.

It speaks of mercury, after a year of subduing fire, disgorging lead above, subdued and dead to form the elixir—called the elixir of True Yang. Thus it is said: subduing fire exposes the form to decay. The scripture states: “In the tenth month, it sheds its womb.” This is mercury, its fire complete, shedding above the lead. The common analogy is that one who seeks the Dao, ingesting *qi*, resting and toiling, erecting altars and offering diligent sacrifices, moved by dreams of spirits manifesting, cherishes joy in the heart and deems it the Way of longevity. Yet such as these cannot escape death. Without ingesting the great elixir, in the end they cannot avoid decay and exposure in death.

Every action taken is an endeavor, yet perversion and rebellion lose the pivotal mechanism. It speaks of subduing mercury to form the elixir—if perverse and not attaining principle, one’s *qi*, intent, and heart become depleted, rebelling and losing the secret method of the pivotal mechanism. Should one seek the method without clarity, one wastes fire and squanders wealth, suddenly losing the path of life and cutting short one’s mandate. Even if the elixir is obtained but its toxins are not understood, hasty ingestion leads to poisoning and the loss of life. This is like those who fail to grasp the principle of the elixir: they waste their efforts in vain, ingesting *qi* and erecting altars, yet in the end cannot escape death, losing the essential mechanism.

The methods are exceedingly numerous, numbering in the thousands and tens of thousands. It speaks of flying elixirs and alchemical stones in myriad formulas, yet the secrets of the great elixir are no more than one or two. These are contained within the *Cantong Qi*, which also expounds two or three methods, clarifying only the yin-yang properties of metals and stones. When mercury is subdued by fire and the elixir turns purple, this is the great returning elixir. No matter what the various formulas claim, they ultimately do not depart from lead and mercury. Simply learning to refine lead essence—when mastered—is to subdue mercury. In their original kind, they are not inherently completed; the wonder lies in human craftsmanship. Thus, those who study the Dao must broadly collect scriptures and formulas, never ashamed to seek guidance from inferiors, for the Dao will not be achieved otherwise. If one clings to arrogance and insists on a single principle, one cannot succeed—or if one does, it will not be wondrous. Therefore, the elixir does not depart from lead and mercury.

An ancient song says:
White mercury begets cinnabar,
Black mercury transforms into yellow elixir.
Within it, the numbers nine by nine,
Five and three transformations unfold.
When it reaches the purple river chariot,
Yellow gold finds no place to rest.

Thus, the great elixir does not depart from lead and mercury; it is merely a matter of transformation by human hands. Moreover, if the great elixir can transmute the five metals into mercury to form treasure, only then is it the great returning elixir. Yet it is rare to see one today who, having learned a single method and subdued mercury to the point of fire, claims it as the great returning elixir—without further methods, how foolish, how foolish!

The great elixir must not be adulterated with gold, silver, or mineral drugs, for then it becomes the supreme poisonous divine elixir. If mixed with various stones, it can only treat illness, yet its toxins harm the body. Only by harmonizing lead and mercury is it the elixir of longevity. Yet I have seen fools who, having learned only the method of harmonizing lead and subduing mercury, claim that frying lead nine times makes the elixir, or burning mercury seven times makes cinnabar. They mix them in the crucible, regulating the male and female, praising the solidity of the stone, or refining yellow elixir, sometimes even taking silver as powder and using gold as mud, blending them with equal parts of male and female, flying and refining them in a bottle. After a year of fire and nurturing, when the time is complete, not even half is achieved—only gold, silver, and lead remain, the rest turned to ash, the numinous mercury having flown away entirely. Such blind fools claim it is a divine elixir, yet after ingestion, the body grows heavy and the waist sinks, toxins suddenly erupting, leading to injury and death. They say this is divine punishment for transgression. How profoundly ignorant of the properties of the medicine! Human life is most precious; once dead, there is no rebirth. To ingest poison is to harm the body—how can the path to immortality be hoped for?

Yet if one understands that lead and mercury form the elixir—even if not yet refined—merely subduing them by fire makes the medicine of longevity. Even if one knows to use lead, if it is not properly obtained, and the lead within mercury is not removed, the lead remains and can be ingested. Thus, lead is but temporarily borrowed as a root—how could it be fit for consumption? Therefore, though the methods are many, one must broadly deliberate and not act hastily. To obtain a minor method and then claim it surpasses all others is incorrect.

To go against the Yellow and the Old, twisting and turning against the Nine Capitals—flying elixirs and alchemical stones originated with the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, then with the Most High Lord Lao. The "nine transformations" refer to the names of Daoist adepts who study and ingest the elixir. The "Nine Capitals" are the nine teachings of the elixir scriptures, which Lord Lao transmitted at the pass to Yin Xi, expounding the methods of three transformations, five cycles, nine returns, and seven reversions, along with various elixir methods. Not limited to one or two, whether before or after, if one does not follow the regulations, it is said to go against and twist the scriptural methods.

The enlightened comprehend its meaning, clearly knowing the path. Let those who study elixir methods be enlightened and understand the method. By collecting many immortal scriptures, they awaken to the principle and thus know the path.

Diligently follow it, day and night without rest. After three years of endeavor, one ascends lightly and travels afar. Unburned by fire, undrenched by water. Able to appear and disappear, ever joyful without sorrow. The Dao is achieved, virtue is perfected, one conceals oneself and awaits the time. It speaks of those who love the Dao, diligently seeking elixir methods, tending the furnace fire day and night without laziness. After three years, the elixir is obtained, and upon ingestion, one attains immortality—Dao achieved, virtue perfected. Unharmed by water or fire, able to sit or stand at will, with a thousand transformations and ten thousand changes, commanding ghosts and spirits, lifespan equal to heaven and earth, ever joyful without sorrow. One withdraws from the mortal world, awaiting the time to ascend.

The Great One summons, moving residence to the Central Continent. The Great One is the immortal lord; the Central Continent is the immortal palace. After ingesting the elixir, with golden bones and jade marrow, one is no longer a mortal body. By practicing hidden virtue, meditating in stillness, cutting off thoughts, refining *qi*, and riding the clouds, the Great One sends jade lads and jade maidens to summon one into the immortal palace.

As one’s merit accumulates, one ascends, receiving charts and records. It speaks of ingesting half a dose and remaining among mortals, awaiting the fulfillment of three thousand merits before consuming the full dose to ascend to heaven. The "records" are the precepts of immortals; the "charts" are the true forms of the Five Peaks. One *jin* of the chart is one dose; four *liang* of the great returning elixir is one dose—this refers to two *jin* of medicine.

The *Fire Record* is not falsely composed, expounding the *Yi* to clarify it. The *Fire Record* refers to the great returning divine elixir, which takes the *Zhou Yi* as its model to clarify the use of hexagrams and trigrams, the turning of the crucible, and the movement of fire. Thus, it relies on the *Zhou Yi* to illuminate its wonders, and it is not falsely composed.

The *Reclining Moon Method* employs the crucible and furnace. The furnace is a cauldron. The crucible is said to resemble an upturned moon or a melon in shape; there is also the *Taiyi* crucible. The White Tiger serves as the pivot for refinement. The *Caotang Commentary* states: "The White Tiger is *yushi* (arsenic)." *Ao* means to decoct. It speaks of using *yushi* as the mechanism for mercury. This is unlikely. For *yushi* is highly toxic; if one refines mercury to whiteness, one should use that which grows naturally in storks’ nests, or employ purple *yushi* and *wuzhuo* grass ash to leach mercury—otherwise, the Three Poisons Ash, Five Alums, and Two Auxiliary Medicines. For the Great Elixir and Great Medicine, *yushi* should not be used. Regarding the White Tiger, there are two interpretations. If it refers to whiteness, then silver is used as the gourd vessel, and silver is called the White Tiger. According to this *Contract*, the White Tiger consists of *jinhua* (golden blossom) and *xuanbai* (mysterious white), ground into a paste and applied to the crucible as the mechanism for mercury. *Ao* refers to fire.

The *Flowing Pearl* receives the sun. Mercury is the essence of the sun, born of the sun, radiant and flowing, smooth as a pearl—hence the name *Flowing Pearl*. Lead enters mercury to undergo the Nine Cycles, and the blossom receives the sun to become the *Flowing Pearl*. Alternatively, when *xuanbai* is placed in a cauldron to hold mercury, it forms sand-like pearls, also called *Flowing Pearl*. Mercury is the essence of the sun, thus it is said to receive the sun.

The Green Dragon accompanies it. The Green Dragon is mercury. Mercury belongs to water, and water corresponds to the number one. Cinnabar belongs to fire, and fire corresponds to the number two. One and two make three, and three corresponds to wood, which occupies the eastern position—hence the name Green Dragon. When the dragon is combined with the *Flowing Pearl* to form the elixir, it accompanies it, just as the White Tiger does. The White Tiger is the essence of the Nine Leads, serving as the mechanism for mercury. It is the refined lead that, when melted into liquid and poured into the Green Dragon’s mercury, after encountering fire, blossoms into five colors—called the *Flowing Pearl*, also known as the *Tally of Heaven and Earth*. This tally transforms the layered blossoms of mercury into the elixir, called the *Returning Elixir*. The *Caotang Commentary* states: "The Green Dragon is *zengqing* (malachite)." This is unlikely. If making the Nine Elixirs, one first uses *zengqing* as water, but this scripture does not employ it.

Raising the east to unite with the west, the hun and po naturally seek one another. The east is the Green Dragon, belonging to wood, which governs the liver; the liver is the yang spirit, called the *hun*, and the *hun* is mercury. The west is the White Tiger, belonging to metal, which governs the lungs; the lungs are the yin spirit, called the *po*, and the *po* is lead. Thus, lead and mercury combine, and the *hun* and *po* seek one another. According to the scripture’s reference to the east and west seeking union, how could it be *yushi* or *zengqing*?

The upper crescent corresponds to the number eight of *Dui*, and the lower crescent also corresponds to eight. When the essences of the two crescents merge, the bodies of *Qian* and *Kun* are complete. Two eights make one *jin*, and the Dao of the *Yi* stands upright without inclining. A *jin* has three hundred and eighty-four *zhu*, which also corresponds to the count of the *Yi*’s lines. The *Formula* states: "The upper crescent’s eight metals are half a *jin* of mercury. The lower crescent’s eight metals are half a *jin* of lead blossom." *Dui* governs metal, thus two eights make one *jin*. A *jin* has three hundred and eighty-four *zhu*, symbolizing the three hundred and eighty-four lines of the *Yi*. Mercury is the sun, and lead is the moon; sun and moon form the character *yi* (change), thus the *Yi* does not incline.

Mercury, by origin, belongs to metal; within mercury is metal, and red metal belongs to the south—hence the name *Red Metal*. Lead belongs to metal because within lead is silver, and white silver belongs to the west—hence the name *White Metal*. It is also called *Metal* because it contains *jinhua* (golden blossom). Another interpretation speaks of the *White Method*: the upper crescent’s *Dui* is eight, and the lower crescent’s *Dui* is eight, totaling sixteen *liang* of silver used to make a gourd vessel for the dry mercury method. *Dui* means union, thus *Qian* and *Kun* are complete. *Qian* and *Kun* are the vessel. The correct explanation refers to the weight of the medicine in *jin* and *liang*.

When metal enters fierce fire, its color does not lose its radiance. The nature of mercury and metal is fundamentally indestructible; when subjected to fire, it does not lose its radiance. After the elixir is formed, its color does not change when exposed to fire—if there are impurities, it will change. It is also said that gold and silver vessels are not damaged by fire. Another saying holds that when gold and silver are used to make the elixir, the metal does not lose its nature.

Since the beginning of creation, the sun and moon have never dimmed their brightness. This metaphor speaks of the sun and moon, which since the opening of heaven and earth have remained constantly bright. It compares the medicine in the crucible, which, when opened for viewing each month, suffers no loss.

Metal does not lose its weight, and the sun and moon retain their forms. Mercury is metal. Its body is as heavy as metal, and mercury itself possesses the forms of the sun and moon: within cinnabar it is the sun, and within mercury it is the moon—thus mercury is the sun and moon, and it is metal.

Rarely does one see fools clinging to this metal, claiming that the Great Elixir requires gold. Thus, they dare not attempt it, unaware that this "metal" refers to mercury and *jinhua*. An ancient song says: "Suddenly use the treasure within the Return, not the gold within the mistake. How could one use true gold and silver to make the elixir? Those who speak of using them are greatly mistaken."

Metal is originally born of the moon. It speaks of *jinhua* being born of lead, and lead is the water of the north, which is the moon—thus metal is originally born of the moon. Metal is the blossom of lead.

At the new moon, it receives the tally of the sun. The sun is mercury. The *Kun* hexagram’s lines all transform into *Zhen* from the first line of the new moon; *Zhen* is the *Direct Tally*, and *Fu* is the *Direct Matter*. *Zhen* is the lower vessel that holds mercury, thus it is said to receive and employ the new moon. In the morning, the *Zhen* hexagram is used; in the evening, the *Gen* hexagram is used. These two hexagrams are employed for one day and one month.

Another interpretation holds that when mercury enters lead, it blossoms into *jinhua*, called the *Tally of Heaven and Earth*—thus it is said that at the new moon, it receives the tally of the sun.

Metal returns to its mother. It speaks of mercury, which is originally the grandson of metal and the child of cinnabar.

Jade is the mother of mercury; now, by firing mercury into cinnabar and transforming cinnabar into gold, it returns to its mother. From gold it reverts to cinnabar, called *golden cinnabar*. The Way of the Returned Elixir is complete.

On the last day of the lunar month, it is enveloped and stored. It speaks of the last day of the month when the fire-qi is full—this is one small celestial cycle. When the numbers of yin and yang are complete, refinement begins anew. Again, from the first day of the new month, it is enveloped and stored, concealing its walls and enclosure, submerged in the cavernous void. The walls are the *Taiyi* furnace; the enclosure is the *Taiyi* crucible; the void is the southern fire constellation. It speaks of gold and mercury concealed within the crucible, receiving the fire of the cavern, latent and hidden, thus called submerged.

Gold recovers its original nature. It speaks of mercury, which originally belongs to gold; now, nourished by the fire of yin and yang, it transforms into golden cinnabar, thus recovering its original nature. The radiance of the crucible then shines. *Xi* means beauty. It speaks of the elixir nearing completion: mercury becomes cinnabar, and the crucible’s medicine gains luminous power and virtue—thus people rejoice.

The numbers of *zi* and *wu* combine to make three. *Zi* is mercury; *wu* is cinnabar. Cinnabar belongs to fire, and the number of fire is two. Mercury belongs to water, and the number of water is one. One and two make three—thus they combine to make three. It is also that mercury has one name but two designations, residing in the south and north.

*Wu* and *ji* are called five. *Wu* is yang and belongs to silver; *ji* is yin and belongs to lead, which is the water of the north, and the number of water is one. Within it is silver, which is white, and the number of metal is four. One and four make five—thus it is called five. It is also the golden blossom within lead and mercury, hence called five.

When three and five harmonize, the eight minerals establish the guiding principle. Three is mercury; five is the golden blossom. The above two explanations combine three and five—thus it is called eight. The eighth month is when metal is at its peak—hence the eight minerals. The world does not understand, claiming that the Great Returned Elixir uses eight minerals—this is a grave error. For when mercury obtains gold, they harmonize together, forming the guiding principle of the elixir.

Breathing in desire for one another, they longingly become husband and wife. It speaks of mercury belonging to wood and lead belonging to metal. Metal is the husband of wood; wood is the wife of metal. The dragon exhales, the tiger inhales—they covet and restrain one another, thus longingly becoming husband and wife. The dragon is mercury; the tiger is the golden blossom. Thus it is known that the Great Return does not rely on yin and yang of the same kind subduing one another. Therefore, no other minerals may assist mercury—only gold and mercury will suffice.

Yellow earth is the father of gold. Yellow earth is metal, used to coat the interior of the crucible with *xuanbai* and golden blossom—called the *golden crucible*. It is not that gold or silver are used to make the crucible; rather, earth gives birth to all things, and metal is born of earth—thus it is the father of gold. Gold is mercury transformed into golden cinnabar.

Another interpretation: it is called the golden transformation of yellow sprouts, bearing the names *wu* and *ji*, which belong to earth. They are used to harmonize mercury and coat the interior of the crucible. Another *Jue* states: yellow earth refers to the flowing *xiongci* of the four yellows. The four yellows belong to earth; earth rules the four seasons, its original form established by fire. Each rules for eighteen days, entrusted to the four seasons, and is used as clay to coat the interior of the crucible. This *Treatise* treasures not the four yellows.

Flowing pearls are the mother of water. Flowing pearls are the golden blossom; water is mercury. Mercury belongs to water—thus it is the mother of water. Another name for flowing pearls and golden blossom, when obtained by mercury, also becomes the mother of mercury.

Water takes earth as its ghost; earth fills water so it does not rise. The *Caotang Annotation* states: use an abundance of yellow earth to press down. Otherwise, according to various *Jue*, one may also use the *Five Talismans of Metal* and the like to cover and support—thus it is known that earth refers to golden blossom, yellow sprouts, and the like, while water is mercury. When subdued by earth, it does not rise. It is not that sulphur, which belongs to earth, is used to transform mercury into cinnabar.

The Vermilion Bird is the essence of fire. The Vermilion Bird is fire—the southern constellation, the essence of fire. It holds balance and regulates victory and defeat. Victory and defeat refer to ascent and descent. When ascending, add charcoal; when descending, remove charcoal. *Pingping* means observing the Dipper’s handle to determine the time by the clepsydra, thus knowing when to regulate the fire.

When water prevails, fire is extinguished, and both die to return to the fertile earth. Water is lead; fire is mercury.

Water, when met with fire, melts into liquid—thus it is said to prevail. When mercury enters within and meets fire, the mercury dies and becomes cinnabar. This cinnabar resembles earth or ash, hence it returns to the fertile earth.

The three natures unite in harmony, their original essence sharing a common ancestor. Earth is the ancestor, the golden blossom. One mercury, two gold, three vermilion—all belong to the same lineage. The three natures together honor earth as their ancestor, thus the ancestor and lineage reunite.

*Jusheng* extends years; the returning elixir may be ingested. *Ju* means great. It surpasses all other elixirs, hence it is called *jusheng*. *Jusheng* is a solar name, also an alternate name for the returning elixir. It is also called the Tenfold Victorious Elixir, Purple Powder, or Golden Sand. When the elixir is completed and consumed, it extends life and grants longevity—ingestion leads to immortality. The nature of gold does not decay, thus it is the treasure of all things. Mercury is originally of gold’s nature; now transformed into golden sand, this sand is most revered and precious, the supreme treasure among all things. It transmutes the five metals, so when gold and mercury form the elixir and one consumes it, one’s lifespan matches heaven and earth. The elixir undergoes a thousand transformations and ten thousand changes; those who consume it transcend decay, achieving immortality without death.

Guardians who consume it gain long life. Those who follow the Dao and ingest this great returning golden elixir attain extended longevity, transforming into feathered immortals who soar through the skies.

Earth travels through the four seasons, guarding boundaries and establishing rules. Earth refers to yellow earth as the crucible, or an iron crucible lined with yellow earth. It may also be lined with yellow sprouts or covered with yellow sprout padding, thus it guards boundaries and sets the rules, ruling as king through the four seasons. Moreover, earth refers to the dual yellows—male and female. The male acts as a general, guarding the four frontiers, hence it is said to guard boundaries. Boundaries refer to the color that envelops mercury. *Gui* refers to the roundness of mercury; *ju* refers to the squareness of gold. Earth governs them, hence the term *boundary*. Both interpretations are valid.

When golden sand enters the five viscera—golden sand being the great returning elixir—it is said that mercury, originally of gold’s essence, after three years of fire, transforms into golden sand. The five viscera refer to the five organs. When one consumes golden sand, it enters the five organs and four limbs. It disperses like wind and rain, causing all impurities to perish. If the body harbors filth, grain qi remains unexpelled, and the seven illnesses, nine worms, and three corpses persist, these impurities will perish upon contact with the elixir. Additionally, if the elixir contains arsenolite, realgar, or malachite, or if fire toxins remain unremoved, they too will cause impurities to perish. Some may not die—perhaps due to a one-year elixir, or the absence of other toxins, or because the individual has long practiced virtue, purifying their intestines and organs, thus avoiding death. Therefore, when crafting the great elixir, do not mix it with mineral medicines.

If creating yellow and white alchemy or transmuting the five metals to solidify mercury, if the toxins are not removed, it will not solidify.

Black spreads to the four limbs, and the complexion becomes radiant and lustrous. After consuming the elixir, the old regain a youthful countenance; the four limbs become moist and supple, sinews firm, and marrow full. White hair turns black, and lost teeth regrow. The elderly revert to youth, robust and vigorous. At sixty, one becomes like a young man; at seventy, an old woman becomes a maiden. A maiden is a virgin—after consuming the elixir, her complexion resembles that of a virgin. An old woman is called *yu*; at seventy, *qi*; at ninety, *yi*. By transforming one’s form, one escapes worldly calamities and is called a *zhenren*.

Humans are endowed with the essence of yin and yang. Now, refining the essence of yin and yang into an elixir, those who consume it transform in appearance, grow feathers, conceal themselves, and undergo metamorphosis. They command ghosts and spirits, attain longevity, and endure. Yin and yang cannot mold them; water and fire cannot harm them. They bid eternal farewell to death, their lifespan matching heaven and earth. With golden bones and jade marrow, they are called *zhenren*. This is the boundless merit of the great elixir—even the three disasters cannot harm them.

When lead powder is cast into charcoal, its color spoils and reverts to lead. This illustrates that mercury is originally of gold’s nature. Now, when burned, it becomes gold; transformed into gold, it becomes sand; and from sand, it becomes golden sand. The returning elixir is like lead powder, originally made from roasted lead mixed with salt and vinegar, then heated over fire until it reverts to lead.

Ice and snow, when met with warm water, dissolve into the Great Mystery. The Great Mystery is water. Like ice and snow meeting yang, they transform back into water, self-regulating and undergoing change. It is also said that when the mysterious subdues gold and mercury to form the elixir, how can it not succeed?

Gold takes sand as its essence, harmonizing with mercury. Gold refers to lead blossoms refined over time. When lead blossoms are extracted, they are called golden sand. Mixing sand with mercury and burning it into yellow cinnabar yields yellow sprouts, also called golden sand. Alternatively, heating yellow cinnabar to extract lead, roasting lead into sand, or smelting lead into sand and combining it with mercury—all these methods are valid.

Those who do not understand may say: grind gold and silver into powder to make sand and mix it with mercury. This is gravely mistaken. Such is the method for creating *goulou* yellow and white alchemy. For elixir-making, only golden blossoms and yellow sprouts will suffice.

The *Caotang* states: using cinnabar or mixing gold with mercury cannot achieve melting. Transformation arises from the genuine; beginning and end follow naturally. It is said that gold and mercury are genuine, inherently capable of transforming into the elixir. From start to finish, they follow one another—without this genuineness, they cannot enter the realm of precious wonders.

To create an elixir for immortality, one must use substances of the same kind. If compounding the great elixir with mercury, it is difficult to control its slipperiness. Moreover, as it belongs to the Greater Yang, without its lead-gold counterpart, it will never achieve the proper principle.

The gold belongs to Greater Yin; only when yang obtains yin does it become of the same kind. The Great Returning Elixir mirrors the natural generation of heaven. The Returning Elixir arises naturally—cinnabar is born in lands where cinnabar exists, taking four thousand three hundred and twenty years to form. At its birth, its radiance illuminates mountains, shining through a thousand *li*. On the days of the Three Origins, the Purple Tenuity Heavenly Officials of the Upper Origin, the various heavenly immortals, and the Jade Clarity Immortal Officials descend to inspect it—something no mortal of a few lifetimes could obtain.

At its birth, above it lies malachite; to its left, realgar; to its right, orpiment; below, gold sand; to the south, cinnabar; to the north, mercury. These are the surging and intermingling *qi* of heaven and earth’s Greater Yin and Greater Yang. After one thousand eighty years, gold ore forms; the ore takes another one thousand eighty years to produce cinnabar; the cinnabar takes another one thousand eighty years to produce mercury; the mercury takes another one thousand eighty years to produce the Natural Returning Elixir—altogether four thousand three hundred and twenty years.

Calculating that one year has twelve months and four thousand three hundred and twenty hours, with one hour corresponding to one year, then one year’s fire *qi* completes the Lesser Returning Elixir; two years’ fire *qi* completes the Middle Returning Elixir; three years’ fire *qi* completes the Great Returning Elixir. This employs the *qian* and *kun* hexagrams to circulate the fire. The two hexagrams have twelve lines, each line governing two and a half days; two lines govern five days, and five days make one *xun*. Together, they total sixty hours. One line is thirty hours; two lines are sixty hours. Calculating one month as three hundred sixty hours mirrors one year’s three hundred sixty days. Thus, one month’s fire *qi* is sufficient, and so the elixir opens once a month.

By this reckoning, one year equals four thousand three hundred and twenty years. When the fire *qi* is sufficient, the Great Returning Elixir is completed. Using three Greater Origins and a half, plus one Lesser Origin—ten years of fire *qi*—accounts for intercalary months and varying month lengths. One thousand three hundred and twenty years make one Greater Origin; sixty years make one Lesser Origin. Now, in crafting the Great Returning Elixir, this *qi* and fire calculation is employed.

Moreover, cinnabar and mercury are especially born in the south, for the south faces Greater Yang, where the sun’s *qi* is abundant and generates them. *The Record of the Ten Continents* states: In Funan, Linyi, and the Five Indias, cinnabar appears like tiles and pebbles. Today, Chen and Jin prefectures, as well as the Five Han regions, have it in great abundance. In the foreign lands south of the mountains, one *dou* and one *sheng* of mercury yields a hundred *jin*. In Chen and Jin prefectures, one *dou* of mercury weighs a hundred *jin*. By this, the mercury of Chenzhou and Wuxi is the finest.

This mercury may be raw or cooked. If it flows out naturally, it is clear and white, sharp and suitable for elixirs. If it is steamed and distilled, it becomes white and turbid, dull and unfit for medicinal use—only good for powder-makers and goldsmiths. Thus, in refining the Great Elixir and great medicines, one must take luminous cinnabar and distill mercury from it to make the elixir.

The cinnabar should be large, three to four *cun* on each side, with veins resembling horse teeth—this is luminous cinnabar, transparent to sunlight. If it is the size of a child’s fist and resembles human teeth, it is called *zhu xiong*. If it is as small as millet grains, it is called cinnabar. If it is white outside and red inside, it is called White Horse-Teeth Cinnabar. Any cinnabar of purple hue is acceptable. The bright red and luminous kind is best; the next, resembling pomegranate seeds, is also usable. All other stones are likewise suitable.

*The Five Metals Formula* states: Gold is hollowed by silver; silver is refined by copper; copper is distinguished by iron; iron is united by tin. Copper is subdued by mercury and free from worry; mercury is moistened by gold; gold is activated by realgar; silver is perfected by realgar. Copper, when matched with realgar, shares an uncommon nature; iron, when matched with realgar, averts danger. Gold, when controlled by orpiment, is momentarily restrained; silver, when matched with orpiment, transforms doubt. Copper, when matched with orpiment, corrects its errors; iron, when matched with orpiment, becomes firm; tin, when matched with orpiment, becomes fittingly lustrous. Thus, substances of the same kind are known to be compatible; those not of the same kind are difficult to subdue. Therefore, the Great Returning Elixir cannot be formed without the mutual restraint of yin and yang.

Hence, the scripture says: Subduing mercury into an elixir allows one to sit upon the Jade Altar. If mercury is refined alone into an elixir, it is the True Unity Method, also called the Wish-Fulfilling Method or the True Unity Independent Practice. Master Nine Origins says: Single refinement is not permitted. Thus, using lead for single refinement, mercury is called Solitary Yang and requires yin medicine.

Moreover, *The Formula* states: Use silver as the same kind. Take eight *liang* of silver powder, seven *liang* of mercury, and one *liang* of realgar. Each month, remove the tiger and add the dragon. The dragon is raw mercury; the tiger is subdued mercury. Refining with *qian* silver is also a good method. Calculating the Great Elixir, there is no principle to it.

Another method: Use a silver vessel to support mercury until it becomes cinnabar, then use refined orpiment and realgar as mud to wrap the cinnabar-mercury and place it in a silver container. Seal it with halloysite and red halloysite, and cover it with red salt—this is called Independent Practice. This method is also of the same kind, though it is mostly a minor purple elixir. Whether it truly succeeds, whether it is toxic, and whether it is suitable for long-term consumption remain uncertain.

Another method: Mix gold with mercury and realgar. Another method: Mix cinnabar with mercury, adding cinnabar each month—this is called the Crimson Dragon’s Repeated Descent, the White Tiger’s Drinking. Another method: Mix equal parts cinnabar and mercury, adding raw sulfur every seven days. Once it becomes cinnabar, place it in a jar. There is also a method using silver, cinnabar, and mercury, adding refined realgar and red salt for twelve months—all of the same kind.

If following this *Contract*, it is not only gold and mercury that are truly of the same kind. Planting grain requires millet as seed. Just as sowing grain requires millet as seed, making medicine requires lead elixir as seed. Once the elixir is formed, use the elixir as seed; the rest are not of the same kind. To subdue a hen, use its egg. This means that to subdue a hen, one must obtain a hen’s egg. Thus, the Returning Elixir must use golden blossoms as its same kind to be completed.

Transforming through kindred nature comes effortlessly; things take form as if shaped by cold forging. When of the same kind, work is easily applied; without the proper seed, no treasure can be made. Thus, the quail does not hatch the phoenix, nor does the fox or hare nurse the horse. Water does not flow upward in flame, nor does fire, though black, moisten downward. This speaks of lead and mercury in union—affairs must harmonize. Once the elixir is achieved, use the elixir as seed, so that things transform through nature, forming as if smelted. If the kind is the same, how could it not become treasure? Those of different kinds—can the quail hatch the phoenix? Can the fox or hare bear the horse? Water does not flow upward, and fire does not burn downward. Thus, we know that only the same kind succeeds; the unlike cannot.

In the world, many scholars possess lofty and wondrous talents. Yet by chance, they do not encounter the right opportunity, wasting fire and squandering wealth. This speaks of how many in the world desire to learn the divine elixir of longevity, admiring the arts of the furnace. Without meeting a enlightened master to reveal the true method, they rely on their own talent, learning but a minor technique and proceeding by guesswork. Some claim to use gold and silver, others male and female mercury, empty cinnabar, and the like. Some say it takes a year, others sixty days, while others speak of nine cycles without clarity in weight. Some, having merely subdued mercury, claim it is the great elixir; others achieve the elixir but fail to subdue the fire. Some, upon failure, grow disheartened and abandon the work; others feel shame and refuse to seek guidance. Through such negligence, the scriptures remain obscure, their progress mired in doubt, leading to failure and loss—discarding fire and wasting wealth. Such cases are many. They rely on fabricated texts, proceeding recklessly by their own notions. The proper origin and cause are absent, and their measures lack steadfast discipline.

Those who refine and prepare chalcanthite, mica, and reputed magnetite—along with sulfur from Yuzhang and lead in its natural flow—engage in mutual smelting and refinement. Those who claim devotion to the Dao and the furnace-fire arts, lacking true instructions, encounter some minor method or seek out ancient texts and various cryptic sayings. They cling to this *Contract*, declaring gold to be silver, calling water "wood," naming the tiger "reputed," calling the dragon "malachite," referring to earth as "realgar," calling golden blossoms "white silver," designating yellow sprouts as "sulfur," and labeling autumn stone as "reputed stone." They claim chalcanthite comes from Pu Prefecture, or else from Qiang Dao. Those who use jadeite do so on their own conjecture, insisting they understand—yet how could they know the divine formulas are profoundly guarded, their true words concealed and obscured? How could chalcanthite emerge from lead, or autumn stone and yellow sprouts both arise from the body of the Golden Lord?

The *Scripture* states that Yuzhang refers to Dao Prefecture, which in ancient times belonged to Yuzhang County in Rao Prefecture—not today’s Hong Prefecture. Yuzhang, along with Dao and Yong Prefectures, produces cinnabar and mercury; today, people mistakenly use materials from Hong Prefecture. To take the earth of Yuzhang as vessels, and to pound mica, reputed stone, magnetite, sulfur, and chalcanthite into an elixir—is this not a grave error? Proceeding by conjecture, the *Scripture* thus says: "Hold to it with proper method and ritual, for I dare not fully disclose the procedures." How could the secrets be revealed so directly? Such practitioners are scarcely worth discussing.

Wan is another name for mercury. The "drumming of the five-stone bronze" refers to its use as the *jin shu* (exhaust-pivot). The *jin shu* is a vessel. Those who, ignorant of its principles, recklessly employ the five metals as their crucible—how could they succeed? The Five Planets and the five metals all emerge from stone, hence the term "five stones." It is not that drummed stone can produce gold or bronze. If refining mercury into silver, one must use a silver vessel; if making the elixir, a clay crucible is required. Using lead without refining the *xuanbai* (mysterious white), merely coating the interior with golden flowers, will achieve nothing. Different lineages do not share the same seed—how could they unite in one body? A thousand attempts will meet with ten thousand failures; what was meant to transmute will instead become delusion. Those who rely on arrogance and luck will never encounter the Way—only the sage truly knows. From youth to white-haired age, they grasp at straws in vain, mired in doubt. Things not of the same kind—how can they be mixed to succeed? A thousand attempts, ten thousand failures, until old age brings no satisfaction, the heart filled with longing and lingering uncertainty. Others, too proud to submit to a teacher, amass scriptures, formulas, and the *Cantong Qi*, exhaust their wealth, and haphazardly mix various stones—yet even in old age, they achieve nothing.

Turning from the Dao to cling to delusion, treading crooked paths into perverse byways: this describes those who seek the *Cantong Qi* and esoteric formulas, only to claim, "The method is not found here." Failing to recognize the true scripture, they bend and twist onto false roads, grasping the Dao while lost in confusion. Is this not the case? Peering through a tube yields no broad vision—how can one thus gauge what lies ahead? It means that those who cling to a single method, or obtain one scripture or one formula, immediately call it wondrous. Yet this is like gazing at the heavens through a tube—how can it compare to a sweeping view of distant horizons?

As for the supreme sages, none surpass Fuxi, who first drew the eight trigrams, modeling them on Heaven and Earth. Fuxi, the Great Hao of the Wood Virtue, looked up to emulate celestial patterns; the dragon-horse emerged from the River bearing the Diagram, and thus he established the eight trigrams. Later, Shennong doubled the trigrams, expanding them into sixty-four. The *Appended Judgments* states: "Heaven engenders transformations, and the sage takes them as his model." King Wen, of the imperial lineage, elaborated the line statements. Later, King Wen of Zhou expanded the *Yi* and determined the line texts and silk words. Confucius, the foremost among sages, composed the *Ten Wings* to aid it. Confucius, the greatest of all sages, thus created the *Ten Wings*—the line texts, Images, Great Commentary, hexagram statements, and lesser Images—totaling ten scrolls, known as the *Ten Wings*. Later, Confucius praised the Dao of the *Yi*, lost in the Images and Symbols. The *Yi* is the subtle and wondrous essence, a book that illuminates the dark and commands destiny. Thus, in the Xia it was called the *Lianshan*, in the Yin the *Guicang*, in the Zhou the *Zhouyi*, in the Han the *Tai Xuan Shu*, and in the Jin the *Tong Lin*. Therefore, the supreme subtlety of the elixir path is entrusted to the imagery of the *Yi*.

The Three Lords were raised by Heaven, each rising in turn to govern their time. Yet even among them, there are gradations in their steps, and their merits and powers cannot be equaled. The world’s greatest sages—none surpass Fuxi, King Wen, and Confucius—were Heaven’s chosen instruments, who drew trigrams, expanded the lines, and composed the *Ten Wings*. They understood the waxing and waning of fortune, yet dared not presume to control the furnace fire or share in its radiance. How much less could lesser men casually grasp the workings of creation? This Dao is profound and obscure; only by personally receiving the fire formulas can one succeed in its practice.

Moreover, before the Three Sovereigns, people were simple and unadorned; after the Five Emperors, worldly methods grew increasingly shallow. Thus, the ancients used two ingredients to complete the elixir, while later generations came to know many stones. This is why their merits and powers cannot be compared. Their creations followed in the footsteps of those before...

The creation of works follows in the footsteps of predecessors, for without like substances, nothing can be accomplished. Weighing and measuring must be precise to the *zhu*. A *zhu* is one part of a medicinal pound, which contains three hundred eighty-four *zhu*—this corresponds to the celestial degrees, so the division of *zhu* must align with the cosmic measures.

What has form is easy to estimate: when mercury obtains the golden flower, it takes shape as cinnabar or the elixir bell, as in the making of yellow and white where gold and silver are blended with mercury—such things are readily gauged. But what lacks signs is difficult to plan. *Mou* means strategy; *zhao*, the foundation. If mercury does not obtain gold, its foundation is hard to strategize. Even water and fire, though visible, cannot be easily regulated—how much more so mercury, which is so wondrously transformative and without trace, making it truly difficult to devise or contemplate.

When the crafting of elixirs is made exemplary, it becomes the established canon for the world. *Fa* means standard. The perfected ones’ alchemical methods are recorded in scriptures, yet people in the world fail to comprehend them. The *Songs* are ancient verses, and the *Book* is the *Cantong Qi*; thus, the *Cantong Qi* elaborates on the ancient verses, and both have been transmitted within it. Though the elixir formulas are clear, people do not grasp their principles and instead devise their own misguided interpretations—just as Confucius edited the *Songs* and established the *Rites* to serve as enduring standards. If one does not understand the *Cantong Qi*, the Dao of the elixir will not succeed, or if it does, it will not endure, for the wondrous transformations of its principles will remain unattained.

The foundational materials—white mercury, gold, lead, and mercury—require prior knowledge, which comes only through a teacher’s instruction. The unrefined substances are not understood without a master; thus, Master Xu himself said he only grasped the Way after learning from his teacher. Now, the *Cantong Qi* and other esoteric scriptures often conceal their secrets, scattering them before or after, so their texts appear disordered. Without prior clarity, one can only awaken through the teachings of an experienced master.

It is like setting up tents in the wilderness without any shelter—what use is there in fabricating empty notions? Or like climbing a high tower with eyes closed—no insight is gained. Those who pursue this elixir path may ascend to great heights, yet if they spend without accomplishment and remain blind to understanding, all is in vain.

The *Fire Records* comprise six hundred chapters, yet their aims do not differ in essence. Though the texts are earnestly expounded, the common people do not ponder them deeply. The *Fire Records* are alchemical scriptures: though the divine elixir and great medicines number over six hundred methods, their paths may vary, but they ultimately converge in a single principle. Fearing that people would not comprehend, the texts repeat their explanations. Why not speak plainly? Because the divine elixir is sacred and weighty, and its secrets were not revealed directly for fear of leaking celestial mysteries. Moreover, the Way of longevity might be severed, and people might cease cultivating the Dao, slandering the world by claiming no elixir of immortality exists. Yet the truth lies close at hand—ordinary people simply do not reflect deeply enough to seek the yin and yang of gold and mercury, which can be understood through a single metal or mineral.

I humbly transmit the words of the worthy ones; how dare I fabricate false teachings? The *words* refer to the scriptures and the *Cantong Qi*. This book speaks truthfully, without deception, and passes it on to later generations. Those who read it with discernment must think for themselves and awaken.

If one were to seal their tongue and sever the Way, they would incur the sin of execution. Yet if I were to speak plainly from the outset, I fear people would not follow the Dao, and so I sealed my tongue and remained silent. I also feared that the Way would be severed and I would be punished. When I set my thoughts to bamboo and silk, I feared leaking the celestial tally. The tally is mercury—it is the heart of Heaven’s mercury, which also generates the five tally-signs.

Hesitating between two paths, I could only sigh in admiration and stitch my thoughts together in foolishness. I began to inscribe my thoughts on bamboo and silk, circulating the text, but feared that revealing too much would sever the Way and bring punishment upon myself. Thus, I wavered between two courses. My thoughts were stitched together in writing, so I concealed my words and spoke in disarray.

From the beginning, there was a method and procedure, yet I dared not lay it all bare. The method of refining the elixir has its own rules and steps. Unwilling to expose the full procedure, I only outlined its essentials, revealing the branches to hint at the root. The work has its method, but I could not explain it entirely—only the guiding principles, the branches that disclose the pattern. Thus, the way of restraint is expressed through the heart of Heaven; symbols are established to convey meaning. If no symbols were set forth, the heart of Heaven would remain unseen. Therefore, I reveal the branches to make its outward form known.

From this point onward, I discuss directly the formation of the elixir from gold and mercury, hence the careful exposition of its steps. Gold serves as the embankment, and when water enters, it flows with ease. The gold here refers to the nine-times-refined essence of lead—golden flower buds. Using golden flowers as an embankment can restrain mercury; this embankment is the method of containment, able to hold the mercury in place, hence the term "embankment." To refine mercury into the elixir, one does not use gold or silver to contain the mercury—that would be the method of yellow and white alchemy. It is also said that gold is used as the crucible, called the "embankment," which is the silver kettle method. This is not what the elixir requires. Only when mercury is harmonized with golden flowers, entering and blending without loss, can it flow with ease.

Originally, it was said that "water" was a miswriting of "wood," which is incorrect. It was also said that azurite was used as wood, but this remains unclear. There are fifteen measures of gold, using fifteen taels of golden flowers. Mercury is volatile and difficult to control, so golden flowers are used. Otherwise, yellow buds serve as the root for containment, using yin to restrain yang. The measure of water is the same: water here is mercury, also fifteen taels, symbolizing the number of a single month.

The *Caotang* states that "water" is a miswriting of "wood," suggesting the use of fifteen taels of azurite, divided into five portions of three taels each. It says three portions of golden flowers (nine taels) and two portions of azurite (six taels) are used, with one catty of mercury. If we speak of the elixir’s method as true, only azurite remains in doubt. The oral instructions all say not to use mineral drugs, so one must carefully consider whether azurite is appropriate. Azurite brightens the eyes and summons spirits—it is the essence of gold, so its use would not be amiss. But if "water" is a miswriting for "wood," calling it azurite may be incorrect. It is also said that gold is mercury, which makes sense, and that wood is azurite, using fifteen taels—this requires further verification.

As the *Caotang* Immortal was no ordinary man, his commentary should not be mistaken. If mercury were taken as wood and called the Azure Dragon, where would the measure of mercury be? If there are measures for both gold and mercury, the lines would naturally correspond, and the tally would not be azurite but true mercury. The ancients practiced using only azurite to refine mercury into the elixir, but this *Cantong Qi* discusses only the two substances, gold and mercury, with no mention of azurite.

When setting up the crucible, determine the weights precisely: five portions of water with a surplus. "Five portions" means three taels per portion, totaling fifteen taels. The "surplus" adds one tael to make a catty. There are 384 grains, corresponding to the *Yi*, so a full catty is used. Earlier, it was said to use fifteen taels, symbolizing half a month, but this does not align with the Way of the *Yi*. When adding the surplus to make sixteen taels, it becomes a full catty, fixed in measure. Another explanation of the "surplus" is that a catty of mercury weighs the same as gold: two inches of gold can weigh one tael. Five portions are mercury, and the remaining five portions are gold, as in the previous eleven, four, six, and five taels, totaling fifteen taels as before.

After the Qian trigram is established, fifteen taels of Kun complete the formation. Thirty days make a month, hence fifteen taels each for gold and mercury. These two are taken as true—only gold and mercury are genuine. Based on this, one might say that "wood" refers to azurite, but this does not align with the numerical system.

The weight of gold remains as it was initially. The bodies of gold and mercury should always retain their original weight, so they must be weighed frequently. Do not let the weight be lost—if it is, the fire must be hastened; if hastened, it must be slightly reduced. If the third does not enter, the two waters accompany it. The three substances contain and receive one another, transforming in a manner divine.

One is gold, two is mercury—water is the third, but it is not a third ingredient. It is said that the third does not enter, and the two are true. How could there be three substances? Only the two, gold and mercury, are refined by fire. After ten months of gestation and sixty days of transformation, they become the True Yang Divine Elixir.

Beneath lies the qi of Great Yang—qi here means fire. The crucible’s base holds the fire. The success or failure of the refinement depends on the fire. If the fire is too hasty, there will be loss; if too restrained, it will not cease, like driving chickens or herding mercury—it is difficult to achieve the proper fire. As previously stated, the fire of the four seasons requires careful attention. Simply let the fire progress from civil to martial, and it will suffice.

Steam it for a brief moment: first it liquefies, then it congeals, and it is called the Yellow Chariot. The unmelting flowers become liquid, and the warmed mercury is added. Another method says to remove the fire after adding azurite powder, let it cool, grind it finely, place it in the crucible, and gradually apply fire as if steaming. After the months are fulfilled, it becomes the elixir, golden and purple in color—hence the name Yellow Chariot.

It is also said: the Yellow Chariot resembles a carriage, and when one ingests the medicine, it elevates the person—hence the name Yellow Chariot. Furthermore, when mercury is initially subdued, it briefly liquefies and then congeals, its color faintly tinged with greenish-yellow—this too is called the Yellow Chariot.

This annotation, along with the preceding discussion on using gold as a barrier, has fully addressed the weights of ingredients, their preparation, and their placement in the crucible. If one still fails to comprehend, the Dao cannot be attained.

As the months and years draw to a close, one’s nature is destroyed and lifespan harmed. This means that when the time is fulfilled, the nature of mercury is broken and subdued by fire. Its form becomes like ash and dust, resembling the dust on a bright window.

After ten months, it emerges from the womb, with mercury alone rising above the lead, crimson as the two primal forces. Beginning at the winter solstice, progressing through civil fire to the summer solstice, then through martial fire to the next winter solstice, the mercury is then opened and rises above the lead—this is called the True Yang Elixir. It appears like dust and ash; the medicine is collected and returned to the crucible.

If the mercury’s fire and qi are insufficient, it remains black as dead charcoal. At this stage, many lose heart, abandoning the process without realizing what follows. Simply continue firing the medicine, and its color will shift to purple.

Just as in refining the Minor Return Elixir, where subduing the fire also turns it to black ash, from which it transforms to brown and later to a red-purple hue, later practitioners often stop upon seeing black. When mercury becomes powder, it is light as dust, losing its original form—do not doubt this. Simply allow it to be nurtured by fire over the course of years, months, and days, and its color will naturally transform into the elixir. When ground, it will be known by its weight.

With a year of firing, it becomes dust. Placed in the Red Gate for another year, it becomes the Great Elixir. Refine and combine them, then introduce them into the Red Gate. The Gate refers to the red earth crucible, coated with golden flowers to turn it red. Thus, the previous dust-like medicine and residue are cast and refined before being placed in the crucible.

The *Two Primordials* states: when refining the elixir, collect the residual lead sand. Alternatively, pound yellow earth into mud and coat the crucible. For the True Yang medicine, after sixty days of martial fire, the elixir turns purple; if not yet purple, continue firing until it becomes a deep purple-red, which is the highest grade, while green-black is the lowest.

For the Elixir of the Two Primordials, if it is to be covered, or for the Nine-Cycled Elixir, each cycle requires four taels of Mysterious White and golden flowers for covering. For the Purple Wandering Elixir, red salt is used as the covering—this is called the Red Gate. Seal its junctures firmly, ensuring it is secure and tight. This means the seals must be made sturdy and dense.

The blazing fire is kindled below, meaning the fire beneath should burn steadily, not too fiercely. As recorded elsewhere, begin with a minor martial fire for seventy days. Day and night, the sound remains keen. This means that when mercury receives fire, it emits a sound like an infant’s cry. If the crying ceases, the mercury has been subdued by fire, so the fire must not stop day or night.

Begin with civil fire for cultivation—here, "begin" refers to the initial stage, which is civil fire. As recorded elsewhere, civil fire is used for 360 days. The middle stage is also civil fire, as previously mentioned with "blazing"—why then is civil fire needed? Because the mercury has been subdued by fire, a minor martial fire is now required. In the end, martial fire is employed.

At the close of the month and the end of the year, martial fire is necessary, followed by a greater martial fire. The crucible must match the color of the fire. For the Pure Yang Elixir, a great martial fire is required to subdue the fire, after which it must be transformed into an ingot, ground into powder, and fired for one cycle—this process ideally requires three years of firing. One year of firing also suffices for ingestion, but without transformation, three years of firing yield the superior elixir. As recorded elsewhere, thirty days of martial fire equate to one year of firing.

Observe with utmost care, carefully regulating the heat. Circulate through the twelve nodes, and when each node concludes, inspect closely. Open and examine it once each month, then wash and return it to the crucible. A node represents one month, hence the twelve nodes.

When the qi is exhausted and life nears its end, rest and death claim the hun and po. Here, "qi" refers to fire, and "exhausted" means depleted. After twelve months of firing, the mercury dies and is subdued by fire. The hun is the mercury, and the po is the lead—thus, over a year, the hun and po disperse and transform into the Great Elixir.

Its color shifts further to purple, resplendently forming the Return Elixir. The Return Elixir is purple and is also called Purple Gold Sand, Purple Powder, or the River Chariot.

Four names it bears: Giant Victory. "Giant Victory" is a solar name, for mercury resembles the sun as Giant Victory. Five names it holds: Ten Victories Elixir. Six names it claims: Great Flowing Numinous Sand, so called because the Elder Lord, crossing the passes and fording the rivers to the Western Lands of Flowing Sands, bequeathed this method to Yin Xi, naming it Flowing Numinous Sand.
