chunks.original_text: 《复》卦以明初起火，十一月坤卦一阳爻化为震《复》卦。 始者，初也。 初从《复》卦而起，渐立萌芽，而既生长，终於《乾》。 长子继父体， 既震卦以明其变。 震，是乾之长子。 谓坤一爻化为震，至四月成乾卦，故继父体也。 因母立兆基。 既坤卦以明其化。 坤为震母，所以因母立兆基，而化为震。 消息应锺律， 黄锺，是十一月之律管名也，故黄锺是十一月一阳爻生之律息。 至五月，应於萝宾之律消也。 十二月二阳爻生，律大吕，《临》卦也。 正月三阳爻生，律太簇，《泰》卦。 二月四阳爻生，律夹锺，《大壮》卦。 三月五阳爻生，律名姑洗，《央》卦。 四月六阳爻生，阳欲绝，阴气兴，律仲吕，《乾》卦； 是《坤》一爻生阳息也。 至五月变《乾》阳爻，一阴爻生，律奠宾，《遘》卦。 六月二阴爻生，律林锺，《逐》卦。 七月三阴爻生，律夷则，《否》卦。 八月四阴爻生，律南吕，《观》卦。 九月五阴爻生，律元射，《剥》卦。 十月阴气灭，阳气兴，应锺之律，《坤》卦。 故阴为消，阳为息，轮环不息。 运此二卦，寒爻看火，所以真人殷动属在於火，其火是阴阳之气也。 故火急即药蝶而失，火缓又恐不伏，所以令消息应律候，则炭数，其药不失色而滋润。 故一年用乾、坤二卦，二卦有十二爻，一爻主一月。 又一月用二卦，主二日半，乾、坤各主十五日。 又一日用二卦，一卦主一时。 是故须消息年月，及日加喊炭数，应於锺律不失之也。 升降据斗枢。 从子至巳阳降，午至亥阴升。 升之时鼎p向上，降之时鼎口向下。 只论反轮鼎器，又是炉上安斗柄。 随月建而顺转亦然，此月建及十二时着火。 三日出为爽，震受庚西方。 既震卦以明言月。 初三日，月出西方庚地。 爽，明也。 庚属震，为坤一爻化为震，是一阳爻生，故震以明。 初一日发火，阳火阳爻当得火气，汞一两变困。 二日阴又起，汞又欲飞。 三日阳爻又伏，汞又歌伏。 十五．日内，汞一飞一伏。 至十五日外，汞半伏，状如月圆满。 稍乾，未全伏火。 八日兑受丁，上弦平如绳。 既兑卦以明其中。 兑是西方金，其卦一阴爻在上，二阳爻在下。 以二阳爻，故月八日月出於丁。 丁者，兑也。 言汞得八日火气，金汞相入成汁，而平未变化。 十五乾体就，盛满甲束方。 既乾卦以明其体。 至十五日，火变坤至乾，故金汞十五日稍乾，就刚卦，如半月圆满。 又其日日出束方，三阳爻足，故云满甲属乾也。 蟾蚝与兔焕； 日月两气双#39。 蟾蛛是月精，铅是也。 兔是日精，汞是也。 言日月二精之气，故云双也。 焕者，明也。 言汞十五日虽乾，如水圆满明净，仍未矩火。 若黄白一月伏火，若作大丹，其汞三百五十日伏火矣。 仍未成丹，喻月水之精，不能自明，皆假日照。 言汞虽灵，不得九转铅精，不能自伏火化成丹。 故经云：覆鹞须得子，种禾须得粟，非类不生长。 汞非铅为种不成丹，黄白'非金银所为句。 而不成宝也。 似兔日之精吐光射於月，故云兔焕明。 蟾蛛眠#41卦节，兔者吐生光。 纸，视也。 铅视汞，汞即铅。 视汞汞，即交汞，乃得铅。 铅则吐光，得火已伏，俱吐精光，似月虽明假日所照，光射天下。 至月晦，日月即同宿，二光并相映，不明名之变化。
chunks.translated_text:
The hexagram *Fu* clarifies the initial kindling of fire. In the eleventh month, the *Kun* hexagram transforms one yang line into the *Zhen* hexagram, becoming *Fu*. "Beginning" means inception. The inception arises from the *Fu* hexagram, gradually establishing the sprout, which then grows until it culminates in *Qian*. The eldest son inherits the father’s body—this is illustrated by the *Zhen* hexagram. *Zhen* is the eldest son of *Qian*. It is said that *Kun*’s single line transforms into *Zhen*, and by the fourth month, it becomes the *Qian* hexagram, thus inheriting the father’s body. The foundation is laid through the mother—this is illustrated by the *Kun* hexagram. *Kun* is the mother of *Zhen*, and thus the foundation is laid through the mother, transforming into *Zhen*.

The waxing and waning correspond to the pitch pipes. *Huangzhong* is the name of the pitch pipe for the eleventh month, and thus *Huangzhong* is the pitch pipe for the birth of the first yang line. By the fifth month, it corresponds to the waning of the *Linzhong* pitch pipe. In the twelfth month, the second yang line is born, and the pitch pipe is *Dalu*, corresponding to the *Lin* hexagram. In the first month, the third yang line is born, and the pitch pipe is *Taicu*, corresponding to the *Tai* hexagram. In the second month, the fourth yang line is born, and the pitch pipe is *Jiazhong*, corresponding to the *Dazhuang* hexagram. In the third month, the fifth yang line is born, and the pitch pipe is *Guxi*, corresponding to the *Guai* hexagram. In the fourth month, the sixth yang line is born, and as yang nears its end, yin qi arises; the pitch pipe is *Zhonglü*, corresponding to the *Qian* hexagram. This is the waxing of yang from *Kun*’s single line. By the fifth month, the *Qian* hexagram’s yang lines transform, and the first yin line is born; the pitch pipe is *Ruibin*, corresponding to the *Gou* hexagram. In the sixth month, the second yin line is born, and the pitch pipe is *Linzhong*, corresponding to the *Zhu* hexagram. In the seventh month, the third yin line is born, and the pitch pipe is *Yize*, corresponding to the *Pi* hexagram. In the eighth month, the fourth yin line is born, and the pitch pipe is *Nanlü*, corresponding to the *Guan* hexagram. In the ninth month, the fifth yin line is born, and the pitch pipe is *Yingshe*, corresponding to the *Bo* hexagram. In the tenth month, yin qi perishes and yang qi arises, corresponding to the *Yingzhong* pitch pipe and the *Kun* hexagram. Thus, yin is waning, and yang is waxing, cycling endlessly.

The operation of these two hexagrams, *Qian* and *Kun*, guides the observation of fire. Therefore, the true person’s movements are governed by fire, and this fire is the qi of yin and yang. If the fire is too swift, the medicine scorches and is lost; if too slow, it may not be subdued. Thus, the waxing and waning must correspond to the pitch pipes, and the charcoal quantity must ensure the medicine neither loses its color nor its moisture.

Therefore, in one year, the *Qian* and *Kun* hexagrams are used, and these two hexagrams have twelve lines, each line governing one month. Furthermore, in one month, two hexagrams are used, each governing two and a half days, with *Qian* and *Kun* each governing fifteen days. In one day, two hexagrams are used, each hexagram governing one period. Thus, the waxing and waning of the year, month, and day must be observed, and the addition or reduction of charcoal must correspond to the pitch pipes without error.

The ascent and descent are based on the pivot of the Dipper. From *zi* to *si*, yang descends; from *wu* to *hai*, yin ascends. When ascending, the crucible’s opening faces upward; when descending, the crucible’s opening faces downward. This refers to the inverted wheel of the vessel, and it is also like placing the Dipper’s handle atop the furnace. It turns in accordance with the monthly establishment and the twelve periods, applying fire accordingly.

On the third day, the moon emerges as dawn—*Zhen* receives *geng* in the west. This is explained by the *Zhen* hexagram. On the third day, the moon emerges in the west at the *geng* position. "Dawn" means brightness. *Geng* belongs to *Zhen*, for *Kun*’s single line transforms into *Zhen*, and thus one yang line is born, so *Zhen* is bright. On the first day, fire is kindled, and the yang fire and yang line receive the fire qi, transforming one *liang* of mercury. On the second day, yin arises again, and the mercury seeks to fly. On the third day, the yang line is again subdued, and the mercury is again restrained. Within fifteen days, the mercury flies and is subdued in alternation. Beyond fifteen days, the mercury is half-subdued, resembling the full moon. It is slightly dry but not yet fully subdued by fire.

On the eighth day, *Dui* receives *ding*, and the first quarter is level as a string. This is explained by the *Dui* hexagram. *Dui* is the metal of the west, and its hexagram has one yin line above and two yang lines below. Due to the two yang lines, the moon emerges at *ding* on the eighth day. *Ding* belongs to *Dui*. It is said that when mercury receives the fire qi of the eighth day, metal and mercury merge into a liquid, level but not yet transformed.

By the fifteenth day, the *Qian* body is established, and it is full in the *jia* eastern direction. This is explained by the *Qian* hexagram. By the fifteenth day, fire transforms *Kun* into *Qian*, so the metal and mercury are slightly dry by the fifteenth day, aligning with the firm hexagram, like the full half-moon. Moreover, on this day, the sun rises in the east, and the three yang lines are complete, thus it is said to be full in *jia*, which belongs to *Qian*.

The toad and hare shine brightly; the two qi of the sun and moon are paired. The toad is the essence of the moon, which is lead. The hare is the essence of the sun, which is mercury. It speaks of the two essences of the sun and moon, thus they are said to be paired. "Shine" means brightness. Though the mercury is dry by the fifteenth day, like water, it is round, full, and clear, yet fire has not yet been applied. If making yellow or white elixir, the mercury is subdued by fire for one month; if making the great elixir, the mercury is subdued by fire for three hundred and fifty days. Yet the elixir is not yet formed, likened to the essence of the moon’s water, which cannot shine on its own but borrows the sun’s illumination. Though mercury is numinous, without the nine-fold refined essence of lead, it cannot subdue fire and transform into the elixir on its own. Thus, the scripture says: To cover the sparrowhawk, one must obtain the young; to plant grain, one must obtain the millet—without the proper kind, nothing grows. Mercury, without lead as its seed, cannot form the elixir; yellow and white, without gold and silver, cannot become treasure. It is like the hare, the essence of the sun, emitting light to shine upon the moon, thus it is said the hare shines brightly.

The toad observes the hexagram’s nodes, while the hare emits its radiance. "Observes" means to see. Lead observes mercury, and mercury is lead. Observing mercury, mercury is exchanged, and thus lead is obtained. Lead then emits light, and once subdued by fire, both emit their essence and radiance, like the moon, though bright, borrowing the sun’s illumination to shine upon the world. By the moon’s darkening, the sun and moon share the same lodging, and their two lights shine together, yet their transformation is not called brightness.

chunks.original_text: 至月晦即相离，离而明。 八日兔形消，十五日蟾蛛全视，故言焕。 至十六日兔景消，吐去其光，故蟾蛛纸卦节。 七八道以#42讫，屈折低下降。 既此卦以明其阴阳之正位矣。 十五日，其阳折损，月满则亏，形渐消灭，变乾为巽，折刚为柔。 七八是十五日至望，亦如从、至中用此，故借此卦用以成乾卦象，故云乾以道讫从朔。 十六转受统，巽辛见平明。 既巽卦以明其喊。 ．至十六日，变乾一爻为巽卦。 一阴爻生，变刚为柔，巽受乾化，故云受统。 统，领也，是巽受领也。 为月十六日，月出於巽，行至辛地，即乃平明。 言至十六日，光明欲伏火而成其丹。 艮直於丙南，下弦二十三。 既艮卦以明其止伏。 艮卦一阳爻在上，二阴在下。 二阴爻生，其乾渐损变为艮。 二十三日，其月行至丙，即平明。 言汞至二十三日，如山不动，鱼鳞以成，若作黄白伏火。 艮，止也。 坤乙三十日，束北丧其朋#43。 既坤卦以明其终。 乾以损尽，三阴爻生，变而成坤。 坤者阴，阴初坤属乙也。 又其月三十日，月亏於乙地。 乙是坤之位，而居西南。 今见乙地束方，晦朔交分，从艮为坤，故日束北丧朋。 《易·坤卦》日：束北丧朋，乃终有庆。 庆者喜以阴就阳，喻铅汞得火交媾后，终成丹而喜也。 若为黄白，是一月用功即了。 若作大丹，即一年火气毕，小还丹成也。 若是月，一月尽以变乾为坤，月月轮环，周而复始，终乎一年，即周天火气足。 节尽相禅与，继际#44复生龙。 节尽，是一月尽也。 禅与者，是从月朔分。 交爻之际，又从坤一爻生震，震为龙，故云生龙。 是前一月毕，以将生汞添之。 若是金丹，即添龙喊虎，入鼎重修。 又重坤初六一阳爻，而起为｀《复》卦，故坤节尽，震复受更，依前相继，坤际而起。 壬癸配甲乙， 甲是阳之始，壬是阳之终。 乙是阴之始，癸是阴之终。 乾主甲、壬，坤主乙、癸。 乾知#45太始，坤代有终，以明变化一周旋也。 亦为药物。 甲乙青龙是汞，壬癸玄武为铅，以二物相配。 乾坤括始终。 言一年、一月、一日，皆用乾、坤二卦运火。 言初发火从乾起坤，即是初起首也。 常用此二卦，故乾为阴之初，坤为阳之初。 乾生於始。 始，初也。 坤主於终。 终，月末也。 故用乾坤二卦，轮环相括结也。 七八数十五， 七八是十五日，即是汞得十五日火。 九六亦相应#46。 四者合三十，《易》气#47索灭藏。 九六十五日，并上七八，合三十，以一月火运讫。 《易》者，药也。 德火运阴阳之气，月月渐灭藏，伏火也。 故阳灭即阴藏，一月一周旋。 故七为少阳，八为少阴，九为老阳，六为．老阴，四者合为三十，成一月，故有阴阳之气，而有灭藏也。 象彼仲冬节，草木皆摧伤。 佐阳请商旅，人君深自藏。
chunks.translated_text:
When the moon wanes, they part, and in parting, there is brightness. On the eighth day, the hare’s form fades; by the fifteenth day, the toad is fully visible—hence it is called radiant. By the sixteenth day, the hare’s shadow vanishes, its light withdrawn, so the toad observes the hexagram’s nodes.

The seventh and eighth days mark the Way’s completion, bending and descending low. This hexagram clarifies the proper positions of yin and yang. By the fifteenth day, yang is diminished; when the moon is full, it begins to wane, its form gradually fading. It transforms from *qian* to *xun*, bending the firm into the yielding.

The seventh and eighth days span from the fifteenth to the full moon, just as the beginning and middle employ this principle. Thus, this hexagram is borrowed to complete the *qian* hexagram’s image, hence it is said: *Qian* follows the Way from the new moon. On the sixteenth day, the transition of governance occurs, and *xun* appears at dawn’s first light. As the *xun* hexagram reveals its yielding nature—by the sixteenth day, *qian* alters one line to become *xun*. A single yin line emerges, transforming the firm into the yielding. *Xun* receives *qian*’s transformation, thus it is said to receive governance. Governance means leadership, for *xun* takes the lead.

On the sixteenth day, the moon rises in *xun* and travels to the *xin* position, where dawn breaks. It is said that by the sixteenth day, the light is about to be subdued by fire to form the elixir. *Gen* aligns with the south at *bing*; the lower crescent appears on the twenty-third day. As the *gen* hexagram reveals its stillness—one yang line above, two yin lines below—two yin lines emerge, and *qian* gradually diminishes, transforming into *gen*. On the twenty-third day, the moon reaches *bing*, where dawn breaks. It is said that by the twenty-third day, mercury, like an unmoving mountain, crystallizes into fish scales, ready for the yellow and white to be subdued by fire. *Gen* means stillness.

By the thirtieth day, *kun* at *yi* in the northeast loses its companion. As the *kun* hexagram reveals its end—*qian* is entirely diminished, three yin lines arise, transforming into *kun*. *Kun* is yin, and yin’s inception belongs to *kun*, which corresponds to *yi*. On the thirtieth day, the moon wanes at *yi*. *Yi* is *kun*’s position, residing in the southwest. Now appearing in the east at *yi*, the dark and new moons intersect, shifting from *gen* to *kun*—hence it is said: in the northeast, it loses its companion. The *Book of Changes*’ *Kun* hexagram states: “In the northeast, it loses its companion, yet in the end, there is celebration.” Celebration comes when yin joins yang, illustrating how lead and mercury, after uniting with fire, ultimately form the elixir in joy. If crafting the yellow and white, a month’s work suffices. If making the Great Elixir, a year’s fire and qi complete it, and the Lesser Returning Elixir is achieved.

For the moon, a month’s end transforms *qian* into *kun*, cycling endlessly. After a full year, the celestial fire is complete. When the cycle ends, succession follows, and at the juncture, the dragon is reborn. The cycle’s end marks the month’s conclusion. Succession begins at the new moon’s division, where lines intersect. From *kun*, one line gives rise to *zhen*, which is the dragon—hence the dragon’s rebirth. The previous month concludes, and fresh mercury is added. For the Golden Elixir, dragon and tiger are added, entering the crucible for refinement. Again, *kun*’s initial six lines yield one yang line, rising as the *Fu* hexagram. Thus, when *kun*’s cycle ends, *zhen* receives renewal, continuing as before, emerging from *kun*’s juncture.

*Ren* and *gui* pair with *jia* and *yi*:
*Jia* is yang’s beginning, *ren* its end; *yi* is yin’s beginning, *gui* its end. *Qian* governs *jia* and *ren*; *kun* governs *yi* and *gui*. *Qian* knows the Great Beginning, while *kun* takes its end, illustrating a full cycle of transformation. These also serve as medicinal substances: *jia* and *yi* are the Azure Dragon (mercury), *ren* and *gui* the Dark Warrior (lead), the two substances paired. *Qian* and *kun* encompass beginning and end. Whether a year, a month, or a day, fire is directed by the two hexagrams *qian* and *kun*. The initial fire begins with *qian* and *kun*—this is the starting point. These two hexagrams are ever used, for *qian* is yin’s inception, *kun* yang’s inception. *Qian* arises at the beginning; beginning is the start. *Kun* governs the end; the end is the month’s close. Thus, *qian* and *kun* cycle endlessly, binding together.

Seven and eight make fifteen—seven and eight are the fifteenth day, when mercury receives fifteen days of fire. Nine and six also correspond. The four combine to make thirty, and the *Yi*’s qi seeks concealment. Nine and six, with seven and eight, total thirty, completing a month’s fire cycle. The *Yi* is the medicine. The fire’s virtue directs the qi of yin and yang, gradually concealing it each month—subduing the fire. Thus, when yang vanishes, yin hides, completing a month’s cycle. Seven is young yang, eight young yin; nine old yang, six old yin. The four combine to make thirty, forming a month, hence the qi of yin and yang waxes and wanes. Like the midwinter season, when grasses and trees wither. Assisting yang, one entreats the merchants; the lord deeply conceals himself.
chunks.overlap_context: while the hare emits its radiance. "Observes" means to see. Lead observes mercury, and mercury is lead. Observing mercury, mercury is exchanged, and thus lead is obtained. Lead then emits light, and once subdued by fire, both emit their essence and radiance, like the moon, though bright, borrowing the sun’s illumination to shine upon the world. By the moon’s darkening, the sun and moon share the same lodging, and their two lights shine together, yet their transformation is not called brightness.

chunks.original_text: 象时顺节令，闭口不用谈。 天道甚浩广，太玄元#48形容。 虚寂不可睹，匡郭以消亡。 谬误失事绪，言还自败伤。 别序斯四象，以晓后生盲。 八卦列布辉#49，运移不失中。 八卦列布，炉八方。 辉，火也。 言太一炉布卦於八方，运火於十二辰。 坎为阳中，阴为离中，不失一阴一阳之道。 鼎在中，其运火转鼎，不失中也。 故乾甲坤乙，天地定位，艮丙兑丁，山泽通气； 震庚巽辛，雷风相薄； 坎戊离己，水火不相射，所以日月行於八卦而经黄道，故不失中。 元精眇难睹， 元精，汞也。 眇，纯粹精。 喻金汞察阴阳二气，象色精微，是天地之灵。 眇难绪，不可见也。 推度效符证。 言运火行卦，皆周天法度，以取真符为证。 居则观其象，准仪#50其形容。 象，谓日月在天成象，在地成形。 运火观鼎，不得失仪式。 推阴阳之气，象时而动，故《易》者，观其气象，察．其成形，以为仪准。 所以徐真人仰观卦象，丹道准此也。 立表以为范， 范，法也。
chunks.translated_text:
As the seasons flow with the节令,
seal the mouth and speak no words.
The Dao of Heaven is vast and boundless,
the Great Mystery’s primal form eludes description.
Empty and still, it cannot be seen—
its frame and bounds dissolve into nothingness.
Errors and missteps unravel the threads of affairs,
words turn back to wound the speaker.
Distinguish and order these Four Images,
to enlighten those blind to what comes after.
The Eight Trigrams array their radiance,
their revolutions never stray from the center.

The Eight Trigrams array their positions,
the furnace spans the eight directions.
Radiance is fire.
Thus the Great One arranges the trigrams across the eight directions,
circulating fire through the twelve branches.
Kan is yang within yin, Li is yin within yang,
never straying from the Dao of one yin and one yang.
The cauldron stands at the center,
as fire revolves around it without losing the center.
Thus Qian is *jia*, Kun is *yi*—Heaven and Earth take their places;
Gen is *bing*, Dui is *ding*—mountain and marsh exchange qi;
Zhen is *geng*, Xun is *xin*—thunder and wind press upon each other;
Kan is *wu*, Li is *ji*—water and fire do not repel,
so the sun and moon traverse the Eight Trigrams along the ecliptic,
never straying from the center.

The primal essence is subtle and hard to perceive—
primal essence is mercury,
subtle as pure, refined essence.
It mirrors the scrutiny of yin and yang’s two qi,
its color and luster exquisitely fine,
the numen of Heaven and Earth.
Its subtlety defies all threads of inquiry,
it cannot be seen.
Yet by calculation and verification, its signs are confirmed.
When circulating fire through the trigrams,
all follows the celestial measures,
taking the true tally as proof.

At rest, observe its images,
gauge its forms by the standard.
Images are the sun and moon forming patterns in the heavens,
taking shape upon the earth.
When circulating fire and observing the cauldron,
do not lose the proper form.
Trace the qi of yin and yang,
move in accord with the seasons—
thus the *Yi* observes their qi and images,
examines their completed forms,
to serve as the standard.
This is how Master Xu gazed upward at the trigram images,
aligning the elixir path to this principle.

Erect the gnomon to serve as the model—
the model is the law.

chunks.original_text: ·言炉上安筒。 昼作十二辰形为漏刻。 子时即鼠头，辰现以顺次见之。 运火转，亦一辰一移，表於十二辰，不令有失也。 候占#51定吉凶。 ． 言依漏刻占候十二卦，以定吉凶。 发号顺时令#52，勿失爻动时。 时，谓十二时。 令，顺四时，勿废其周易参同契注卷上号令。 故春养秋成，夏长冬藏，刚极则亢，阴极则邪，一以贯之，莫失四时之道。 若《巽》卦先庚，《蛊》卦先甲，言运火转器，皆依乾、坤二卦。 又生变发动，顺时应令者也。 上察河图文， 文，天文也。 河图，八卦也。 言运火常察八卦所在，故《易》日：观乎天文，以察时变。 下序地形流。 序，置也。 言上置炉电、药院等，须择名山，选於胜地，顺其地形水流，向利则吉也。 中稽於人情#53， 论合丹好道。
chunks.translated_text:
On the furnace, install a tube. By day, fashion it into the twelve earthly branches to serve as a water clock. At the hour of *zi*, the rat’s head appears, and the branches manifest in sequential order. As the fire circulates and turns, it shifts one branch per movement, marking the twelve branches without error. Observe and divine to determine fortune or misfortune.

This means to divine the twelve hexagrams according to the water clock, fixing auspice or inauspice. Issue commands in accord with the seasons, never missing the moment of moving lines. The *times* refer to the twelve hours; the *commands* follow the four seasons, never neglecting the cyclic measures of the *Zhouyi Cantong Qi*. Thus, in spring one nurtures, in autumn one harvests, in summer one grows, in winter one stores. When yang reaches its extreme, it becomes excess; when yin reaches its extreme, it turns perverse. All is threaded as one, never straying from the Way of the four seasons.

As in the *Xun* hexagram, where *geng* comes first, or the *Gu* hexagram, where *jia* comes first—when circulating fire and turning the vessel, all follows the two hexagrams *Qian* and *Kun*. Further, when generation, transformation, and activation occur, they align with the seasons and respond to the commands.

Above, examine the patterns of the *Hetu*;
the *patterns* are the celestial configurations.
The *Hetu* is the eight trigrams.
This means that when circulating fire, one must constantly observe the positions of the eight trigrams, for as the *Yi* says: *"Observe the celestial patterns to examine the changes of the times."*

Below, arrange the earth’s forms and flows.
*Arrange* means to position.
This speaks of placing the furnace, the crucible, the medicine courtyard, and the like—one must choose a renowned mountain, select an auspicious site, and align with the land’s topography and water flow, facing the propitious direction for good fortune.

In the midst, consider human nature,
discussing the union of the elixir and the love of the Way.

chunks.original_text: 稽，考也。 同共营丹之士，须考其情。 和纯志道，即可共为事丹道。 参合考三才。 三才，天、地、人也。 夫合丹炼药，事乃非轻。 上择吉辰，则其星象。 下观其地，背阴向阳。 中考人情，宜须温善。 飞丹炼石，皆通神明者。 不择地山，精损人。 不定阴阳，丹有危败。 自心有虑处，同伴亦疑。 二人如此顺和，不可造次营合。 故河洛出图，圣人所作如周、召相宅，营於洛、吶。 三才若有备，叉元休咎。 动则循卦节#54，节， 言冬、夏二至。 夏至后，依乾、坤卦，所以运火，皆据乾、坤爻动而变。 静则因#55《象》辞。 故《象》者言乎象，爻者言乎变，所以阳动阴静，因循卦节。 言运火皆逐阴阳动静变化，如《象》辞动静。 乾坤用施行，天下#56然后治。 可不顺#57乎？ 言若依乾、坤运转，刚柔施行，何所不从。 故乾道施仁，坤道施义，故天下理，四时岂不顺乎？ 如君臣有德施行万姓，宇宙之问，可不顺之安泰也。 御政之首。 御，统也。 政，理也。 首，始也。 言常守御依理，存终始治也。 管括微密， 管，钥也。 括，结也。 微，细也。 言固济如关结镍钥，令甚微细牢密，其精不失也。 开舒布宝。 言每月一开，研治陶洗。 增龙，喊虎，涂土，更依前月。 安布二宝，内於器中，日满开舒成丹。 要道魁柄#58，统化纲纽。 纽，带也。 言炉上安秤茎，以北斗柄承其漏水。 斗柄指月建，转斗鼎运火皆以助之。 纽是斗边安之，又伏汞作乾银壶子，即着小长镍子系如带，常纽系鼎悬炉中汞。 若欲走其镍，即动即须蘸水。 又丹器若铄鼎日然，须蘸水者，西方之王，金得刚而制，喻将伏汞铃顺元失。 又《易》者是变化之纲纽，还丹亦然。 爻象动内#59吉凶始起#60。 依爻象卦，顺阴阳而动。 鼎内吉凶，起失顺之。 五纬错顺，应而#61感动。 五纬，五星也。 言器为镇星，火为荧惑星。 上安水为北辰星，金花为太白星，汞为岁星。 四时若应，铃元动败，不以丹则元感应。 四七乖戾，侈离俯仰#62。 四七，二十八宿也。 侈，奢也。 人若奢佚不勤，药则离散。 俯仰者，是．一日反鼎也。 故运火须依二十八宿也。 文昌总录#63， 文昌者，言北斗边六星名，主六官也。 几典录总称，诂问众星。 喻丹道，皆依星象主之。 诂责台辅。 辅，是北斗辅星也。 是鼎，言上安斗，下安鼎，象之北斗星台。 三台，星名也。 三钉，配合也。 各有所主，令文星主也。 百#64官有司，各典所部。 部，管也。 司，掌也。 言烧大丹，皆取象天地、星宿、日月，各有所掌。 管，典录者也。 日合#65五行精， 日者，汞也。 汞感五行之精，上升为日。 朱砂为火，火精化为青龙，为木精。 水银为水精也。 其汞形而白#66如银，号为湿银，为金精。 化为金花，又为土精，故合五行精也。 月受六律纪。 月，金公也，属阴。 阴六为纪汞，阳六为律调，金汞含阴阳之正气，故受律纪之德而为丹。 五六三十度，度竟复终始#67。 五六三十日，是一月也。 取前日月，借五六之数以为一月，故每月看所以不过一月。 度者，是度数。 计一日、一月、一年，皆周#68天度数。 一日行一度，三百六十日一周天。 月一日行十二度。 一云：十三度一月一周天。
chunks.translated_text:
To examine means to investigate. Those who jointly cultivate the elixir must scrutinize one another’s dispositions. Only when their aspirations are harmonious and their devotion to the Way is pure may they collaborate in the work of the elixir. This is the synthesis and examination of the Three Powers. The Three Powers are Heaven, Earth, and Humanity.

The task of compounding the elixir and refining the medicine is no trifling matter. Above, one selects an auspicious time and observes the celestial configurations. Below, one surveys the land, positioning the site to face the sun and turn from the shade. In the midst, one examines human nature, ensuring that temperaments are gentle and kind. The sublimation of the elixir and the refinement of the stone are matters that commune with the divine. To neglect the selection of mountains and earth is to deplete one’s essence and harm the practitioner. To fail in determining yin and yang is to risk peril and failure in the elixir. Where the heart harbors misgivings, even companions will doubt. If two people are thus in accord, they must not act hastily in their joint endeavor.

Thus, the *Hetu* and *Luoshu* emerged as diagrams, and the sages—like the Duke of Zhou and the Duke of Shao when siting the capital—established their enterprise at Luoyang. When the Three Powers are fully prepared, there will be no omens of fortune or misfortune. In action, one follows the nodal points of the trigrams—these *nodes* refer to the winter and summer solstices. After the summer solstice, one relies on the *Qian* and *Kun* trigrams to circulate fire, for all transformations in the circulation of fire are based on the movements of the *Qian* and *Kun* lines. In stillness, one adheres to the *Xiang* commentary. Thus, the *Xiang* speaks of images, while the lines speak of change; yang moves and yin is still, and one follows the nodal points of the trigrams. This means that the circulation of fire must follow the dynamic and static transformations of yin and yang, just as the *Xiang* commentary describes movement and stillness.

When *Qian* and *Kun* are put into practice, the world is then governed. How could one not follow this? If one circulates fire in accordance with *Qian* and *Kun*, applying firmness and yielding in due measure, what could not be achieved? Thus, the Way of *Qian* bestows benevolence, and the Way of *Kun* bestows righteousness; when the world is ordered, how could the four seasons not proceed in harmony? Just as when ruler and minister, through virtuous governance, bring peace to the myriad families, how could the realm not enjoy tranquility and prosperity?

**The Primacy of Governance**
*Governance* means to unify; *rule* means to order; *primacy* means the beginning. This speaks of constantly upholding governance in accordance with principle, preserving order from beginning to end.

**Sealing with Meticulous Care**
*Sealing* refers to the key; *binding* means to fasten; *subtle* means fine. This speaks of securing the crucible as if locking it with a key, ensuring that every detail is tightly bound so that the essence does not escape.

**Unfolding and Displaying the Treasure**
This means that once a month, one opens the vessel to grind, refine, and wash the ingredients. One augments the dragon and restrains the tiger, applies the earthen seal, and then repeats the process of the previous month. Having arranged the two treasures within the vessel, when the days are fulfilled, one opens it to reveal the completed elixir.

**The Pivotal Handle of the Essential Way**
The *pivotal handle* is the guiding principle. One places a balance beam atop the furnace, with the handle of the Northern Dipper aligned to receive the dripping water. The handle of the Dipper points to the lunar station of the month, and the turning of the Dipper’s handle assists in the circulation of fire within the crucible. The *binding* refers to the attachment at the Dipper’s side. One also subjugates mercury to form a "heavenly silver vessel," fastening it with a small, elongated chain like a belt, constantly binding the crucible and suspending the mercury within the furnace. If the mercury threatens to escape, one must immediately quench it with water. Likewise, if the elixir vessel or crucible becomes scorching hot, one must quench it with water. The Western King governs metal, which is tempered by firmness; this analogy illustrates the need to subjugate mercury and prevent the loss of primordial essence.

Moreover, the *Yi* is the guiding principle of transformation, and the reversal of the elixir is likewise governed by it.

**The Rise of Fortune and Misfortune within the Lines and Images**
One acts in accordance with the lines and images of the trigrams, moving in harmony with yin and yang. Within the crucible, fortune and misfortune arise from adherence or deviation.

**The Five Planets in Disarray or Alignment, Responding to Stimuli**
The *Five Planets* are the five stars. The vessel corresponds to Saturn, the fire to Mars, the water placed above to the Northern Star, the golden flowers to Venus, and the mercury to Jupiter. If the four seasons respond appropriately, there will be no failures or setbacks; without the elixir, there would be no resonance.

**The Twenty-Eight Constellations in Discord, with Excess and Reversal**
The *Twenty-Eight Constellations* are the twenty-eight lunar stations. *Excess* means extravagance. If one is indulgent and negligent, the medicine will scatter. *Reversal* refers to inverting the crucible once a day. Thus, the circulation of fire must follow the twenty-eight lunar stations.

**The Literary Glory Compiles the Records**
*Literary Glory* refers to the six stars beside the Northern Dipper, which govern the six ministries. All records and compilations are collectively overseen, and the movements of the stars are consulted. This analogy illustrates that the Way of the elixir is likewise governed by celestial configurations.

**The Censorate Demands Accountability from the Assistants**
The *assistants* are the auxiliary stars of the Northern Dipper. This refers to the crucible, where the Dipper is placed above and the vessel below, symbolizing the Northern Dipper and its platform. The *Three Terraces* are star names. The *three nails* represent the alignment, each with its own governance, with the literary star presiding.

**The Hundred Officials Each Oversee Their Respective Domains**
*Domains* refer to jurisdictions; *offices* refer to responsibilities. This speaks of the great elixir, which draws its symbols from Heaven and Earth, the constellations, the sun, and the moon, each with its own governance. The *records* are the overseers.

**The Sun Harmonizes the Essences of the Five Phases**
The *sun* is mercury. Mercury responds to the essences of the Five Phases, ascending to become the sun. Cinnabar is fire, and its essence transforms into the Azure Dragon, the essence of wood. Mercury is the essence of water. In its form, mercury is white like silver and is called "liquid silver," the essence of metal. When it transforms into golden flowers, it becomes the essence of earth. Thus, it harmonizes the essences of the Five Phases.

**The Moon Receives the Measures of the Six Pitch-Pipes**
The *moon* is Metal Elder, belonging to yin. Yin’s six measures govern mercury, while yang’s six pitch-pipes regulate it. Metal and mercury contain the true qi of yin and yang, thus receiving the virtue of the pitch-pipes and measures to become the elixir.

**Five and Six Make Thirty Degrees, Completing the Cycle to Begin Anew**
Five multiplied by six equals thirty days, which is one month. One borrows the numbers five and six to represent a month, thus observing the process within a single month. *Degrees* refer to the divisions of the celestial sphere. One calculates the degrees traversed in a day, a month, or a year, all of which complete a full cycle of the heavens. The sun moves one degree per day, completing a full cycle in 360 days. The moon moves twelve degrees per day. Another account states that it moves thirteen degrees per day, completing a full cycle in one month.

chunks.original_text: 天则一日一夜行三百六十度四分度之一。 一周天三十日，皆日月一合。 正月合在亥，二月合在戌。 左行，乃在十二月合在子。 所以运火皆依二十八宿度数，遍历看之。 终始者，是一月度毕，又一月起者。 原本要终，存亡之绪。 阳为始，阴为终。 阳亢阴极，除邪则亡。 原始反终，死亡之道也。 物极则反，月尽复生，所以每月一开看，知存亡、得失、更续。 绪，相添入更造也。 或君骄逸#69，抗满#70违道。 君是火，号日阳君。 若文武不调，铃有抗逸於道。 又君者为金，不得多分两者也。 或臣怀佞#71行不顺轨。 臣，阴水也。 上安水当行。 顺轨，令平而满。 又云汞若多分两於雄黄，失切须慎之。 弦望盈缩，乘变#72怯咎#73。 言汞得火八日上弦欲平生，至十五日望欲乾成砂，二十三日下弦欲伏化，故金汞一月之问乃有盈缩。 故象日月有盈反也。 若不顺，即有怯咎。 如君臣不务於道，如日月薄蚀，五星孛彗，天垂殃咎。 若修丹泄秽，则神灵惩罚殃咎，故注精谨者。 执法刺机#74，请过移主#75。 言修丹运火，心不精勤，不执法录，致失机过。 主者，汞也。 心铃移动不在，如国有执正，忠臣见君有过，方便谏之，冀君应机移改。 若丹衍不修精馑，神铃殃过人也。 辰极受正#76， 辰，北辰星也。 言鼎如北辰星之不移正，受灵汞元不失。 众星仰之，亦依日辰正位而行者也。 优游任下。 任下，火也。 任火调适，汞在器中，．优游四时。 又失文武不均，下火养之。 火若急，即药飞有失。 若在药，亦憔枯色弱也。 喻如北辰为君受国，王理委以臣佐，优游百姓，如北辰众星所仰之。 明堂政德#77，国元害道。 明堂，言器也。 火字于明炉，均调鼎器，坚固蒙密，即元害也。 炉喻国，鼎喻君，以政德兴道，天下太平，国元邪害者也。 内以养己，安静虚元。 己者，药也。 内，是器内。 若内外安静，即能养成丹。 元虚失如人凝淡，虚寂其心。 安静，即内智自明养己。 原本隐明，内照形骸#78。 言金汞如日月为明，隐於鼎内。 得火於金，成汁受於汞，形本为一体，白而且静，内当自照。 火气足后，汞自吐出花居铅上，故见形骸。 此是元阴之丹。 若黄牙为根之丹，汞入花芽之后，研之成粉入鼎，如丹其花芽，得火日久，自为灰形，露出铅骸。 喻如坐忘遗照，玄览澄凝，内照自见，五脏内朗，明彻而成道也。 闭塞其兑，筑固灵株。 灵者，汞也。 株者，金花也。 兑者，鼎口也。 筑者，固际也。 言牢固塞际口，莫令灵汞飞失。 喻如人口为门，舌为钥。 钥动即门开，口舌不慎，於祸而出。 三光陆沈，温养子珠。 珠子，汞也，亦名长生子，亦名流珠。 三光者，日、月、星也。 日为汞； 月为金； 星为鼎，亦为药。 三光者，水、土、金三物也。 陆沈者，火也。 谓金汞得火，温养变成丹。 喻三光者，人之三官。 陆沈为六府。 存三官之气，灌於六府，温养精神，神令不散，魂魄长存。 丹道亦然。 得四时之火，温养三光，神丹即成也。 视之不见，近而易求。 言汞在其内变化不可得见，其法在近而可易求。

chunks.original_text: 故《老子》日：视之不见，名日夷。 夷者，希夷之道。 故不可见，求之不远，心悟乃通。 成准如银壶，伏汞为白，汞在壶子内。 一时一分一四分度之一，每上鼎为一刻，一日一夜有二十四刻，一月有七百二十刻，计汞一·月死，伏火成宝也。 此是分刻，非漏。 一日，百刻也。 其汞若伏，至月末其瓶通红，赤玲即白。 如微有黑点，未伏此，作黄白法。 其先结汞为砂入壶也。 视之不见，为药即不可见者也。 黄中渐通理，润泽达肌肤。 言金汞得火温养。 玉之所化，日月久后，火多渐渐成丹，紫色润泽，人之所服，达於肌肤。 初正则终修， 言月初正理入器，日终重以修理也。 干立未可持。 干，乾华也。 言将本乾花芽研入亦可，火镕花成汁入汞。 或先乾汞朱砂，皆立为本Q研入花芽等为末。 如粉可持入鼎，不得其本为种类，万元一失，成丹之日入干持。 成丹之日入干持，干也如人才虽干秀，道与行违，托意自裁，兼用势望，亦未可修於丹衍。 故知修丹得本类，如元本难成。 本，是金花、黄芽也。 一者已#79掩蔽，俗人莫能知#80。 一者，道也。 故人知一，万事毕。 一是水银，水银属北方水。 水数一，一是法。 又一是铅，铅黑属水，水数亦一。 铅中有白金掩蔽，铅中子含其母二义，故俗人#81莫能知也。 上德元为，不以察求。 下德为之，其用不休。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus *Laozi* states: "That which is seen yet unseen is called *yi*." *Yi* is the Dao of *xi* and *yi*—the subtle and imperceptible. Though invisible, it is not distant to seek; only through the awakening of the heart is it grasped. The standard is like a silver crucible, where subdued mercury turns white, the mercury residing within the vessel. Each moment—one division, one quarter-degree—when placed upon the tripod marks a *ke*. A day and night comprise twenty-four *ke*; a month, seven hundred twenty. By this reckoning, mercury dies in one month, subdued by fire to become treasure. This is the division of *ke*, not the water-clock’s measure. A day consists of one hundred *ke*. When mercury is subdued, by month’s end the vessel glows crimson, its red radiance turning white. Should faint black specks remain, it is not yet subdued—proceed with the method of yellow and white. First, coagulate mercury into cinnabar and place it in the vessel. "Seen yet unseen" refers to the elixir, which remains invisible.

Within the yellow, principle gradually permeates, moistening and nourishing to reach the skin. This speaks of gold and mercury tempered by fire. As jade transforms, after long days and months with abundant fire, the elixir gradually forms—purple, lustrous, and moist. When ingested, it suffuses the skin. "At first rectify, then refine to the end" means that at the month’s beginning, the principle is rightly placed in the vessel, and at its close, it is further refined. "The stem stands, yet cannot be grasped"—*gan* is the blossom of *qian*. It signifies that the original *qian*-blossom buds may be ground and added, or fire-melted blossoms turned to liquid and combined with mercury. Alternatively, dry mercury and cinnabar first, then grind them with blossom buds into powder. Like flour, it may be placed in the tripod. Without the root as its kind, there is no foundation; a single misstep renders all futile. On the day the elixir forms, it enters the *gan* to be grasped. Yet even if the *gan* is as one whose talent, though refined, conflicts with the Dao and conduct, who clings to self-will and relies on power and prestige, it remains unfit for the cultivation of the elixir’s flourishing.

Thus, to cultivate the elixir, one must obtain its root-kind—without the original root, it is difficult to succeed. The root is the golden blossom and yellow sprout. One is concealed—#79 veiled, unknown to the vulgar. That "one" is the Dao. Therefore, "one who knows the One completes all things." The One is mercury, which belongs to the Water of the north. The number of Water is one; one is the method. The One is also lead—black lead, which belongs to Water, whose number is likewise one. Within lead lies concealed white gold; the child within lead contains its mother in two senses, hence the vulgar #81 cannot know it.

Supreme virtue is originally non-action, not seeking through scrutiny. Inferior virtue acts, yet its function never ceases.

chunks.original_text: 上德之人，元名之士； 元为元事，元欲无思； 心若死灰，形同枯木； 坐忘内照，唯慕长生； 不求利养，乃修丹卫； 志在求成，唯在一心，不以察求诸事。 下德之人，是显名之士，用为而求，口虽好道，心在黄白，唯贵名贵财，色性耽学，得丹方即显，且日使用而不休，泄漏天符，去道甚远。 若修丹者隐德合道，即合大道，丹法铃成。 露泄名丹，为科铃败矣。 上闭则称有，下闭则称元。 元者以奉上，上有神德居。 有者，药也。 元者，空也。 上闭称有者，是上釜则药飞上。 下闭则下釜，即药空。 以此返转鼎器，水奉上下，故神丹上居。 上有下元，是其理也。 此两孔穴法，吟气#82亦相须。 言两孔穴是上下二鼎也。 开闭汞於鼎中，得火气作呻吟声，故龙吟虎啸，龙虎在内，故内相须。 从首至北，论以运火，卦爻鼎器，君臣道德，为此丹道，至尊至贵，故言君臣之德也。 以下渐论丹意者也。 知白守黑，神明自来。 白是水银，黑是金公。 金公守，得其汞，故神明自来也。 白者金精，黑者水基。 金精，汞也。 为是金之孙，又号湿银，故曰金精。 黑者，金公q金公属北方水，故日水基。 白为、银，是一义。 又金精者，是汞入金公中吐花，号日金精，亦名玄黄之花，亦名金花。 故金公得汞，即金花之精流。 见金公色黑，即汞之根基。 而吐黄牙，名日金公。 黄之花，亦号单门，亦名紫粉，亦号立制石，亦名石胆，亦名流珠，亦名秋石，亦名玄白，亦名黄轻，亦名天地之符，亦名天地之约，亦名河车，亦名金狗，亦云金虎，甚有多名，不能具录。 所以合丹不得花牙为根。 及涂鼎器，及覆藉固际等，万元一成。
chunks.translated_text:
The person of supreme virtue is one of nameless origin; they act without contrivance, desire without thought. Their mind is like dead ashes, their form like withered wood. Seated in oblivion, they inwardly illuminate, yearning only for long life. They seek no profit or sustenance, yet cultivate the elixir’s defense. Their resolve lies in attainment, focused solely on the One, never scrutinizing external affairs.

The person of inferior virtue is one of manifest renown, acting with purpose and seeking. Though their mouth professes love for the Dao, their heart covets alchemical gold and silver. They prize fame and wealth, indulging in sensual pleasures and learning. Once they obtain the elixir’s method, they flaunt it, using it ceaselessly, leaking the celestial tally and drifting far from the Dao.

If the elixir-cultivator conceals their virtue to align with the Dao, they merge with the Great Dao, and the elixir’s method is surely perfected. To reveal the named elixir is to invite the law’s penalty and failure.

When the upper is sealed, it is called "being"; when the lower is sealed, it is called "non-being." Non-being serves the upper, where the numinous virtue resides. "Being" is the medicine; "non-being" is emptiness. When the upper is sealed and called "being," it is the upper crucible where the medicine ascends. When the lower is sealed, it is the lower crucible, and the medicine is empty. By reversing the vessel thus, water serves above and below, and the divine elixir resides above. The upper holds the lower’s non-being—such is the principle.

This method of the two apertures also requires the breath’s #82 sighing. The two apertures refer to the upper and lower crucibles. Opening and closing the mercury within the crucible, the fire’s qi produces a moaning sound—hence the dragon’s roar and tiger’s howl. Dragon and tiger are within, thus they mutually require one another.

From the head to the north, the fire is circulated through the hexagrams, crucibles, ruler and minister, and the Dao’s virtue—this is the elixir’s path, most revered and noble, hence called the virtue of ruler and minister. What follows gradually expounds the elixir’s meaning.

To know the white and guard the black is to invite the numinous illumination. The white is mercury; the black is Metal Elder. When Metal Elder guards, it obtains the mercury, and thus the numinous illumination arrives.

The white is the essence of metal; the black is the foundation of water. The essence of metal is mercury. As the grandson of metal, it is also called "moist silver," hence "essence of metal." The black is Metal Elder—Metal Elder belongs to the Water of the north, thus called the foundation of water. The white, as silver, is of one meaning.

Moreover, the essence of metal is when mercury enters Metal Elder and spouts a blossom, called the essence of metal, also named the "mysterious-yellow blossom" or "golden blossom." Thus, when Metal Elder obtains mercury, the essence of the golden blossom flows forth. Seeing Metal Elder’s black color, it is the root-foundation of mercury, which sprouts the yellow sprout—hence named Metal Elder.

The yellow blossom is also called "Single Gate," "Purple Powder," "Standing Control Stone," "Stone Gall," "Flowing Pearl," "Autumn Stone," "Mysterious White," "Yellow Lightness," "Tally of Heaven and Earth," "Pact of Heaven and Earth," "River Chariot," "Golden Dog," or "Golden Tiger." It has many names, which cannot all be recorded.

Thus, in compounding the elixir, one cannot do without the blossom and sprout as the root. For anointing the crucible, covering and sealing its edges, and other methods, if even one step is missing, it will not succeed.

chunks.original_text: 水者道枢，其数名一。 为铅汞，俱属北方水。 水数一，谓天一以生水。 又道生一，一为五行之初，道之枢机，故用铅汞各一斤。 据此经所说，用汞一斤，应天之度，应《易》之数，即是阴元之丹，以一斤为一剂。 若用朱砂一斤，黄丹覆藉，名阳元丹。 若专阳化之丹，即用黄牙。 不者，金花一两为本，月月而添，九月计得三十斤，亦名特行九转法。 故还丹之法，乃有数家，变转虽乃不同，造作还同一法。 得理由人，并是大丹。 但至伏火，即是上上神仙之药也。 阴阳之始，玄含黄牙。 为铅，属水，故称玄。 矿铅内有黄牙，如金状，故号黄牙。 五金之主，北方河车。 故铅外黑，内怀金华。 阴者金公，阳者汞。 五金者，铅名也，亦金公也。 金公者，铅名也。 谓铅内怀五彩，造五色之金，故号五金，为汞之主，为属於水，能载丹船。 又如车乘，故号河车。 内有金色，故怀金花。 若黄丹所化，玲凝如镜，打破如马牙，乃号黄牙。 若贵黄牙者，未杯矿铅，是其金花与黄牙，虽俱出铅中，造作有别。 金花者，是取九转铅去除，上如镜，计一斤铅投入汞四两。 ．一云二两。 诸家所说不同，或云等分，或云四六，多应不尔，唯三四为宝。 所以古人有秘，入汞唯须急下火半日，即金花吐状如云母五色玄黄，以铁七接取。 若金花令色不变如金，即是汞花。 若玲后色变带青，青即是铅花。 其花不中，造亦元花出。 有汞即有花，花尽更投汞，取足即休。 亦云：不要九转铅，多应不尔。 不者，亦须三转始可出花。 若依此《契》云，即将其花一斤烊成汁，入汞一斤凝，捣碎入鼎。 若专阳之丹，即将花以铅砂，郁一百日，令花赤色而褐，一两花入生汞一两，和研如粉入鼎。 其郁花名日秋石，亦名立制石。 作若特行将花涂鼎，唯入生汞，不限多少，亦得成丹。 若作黄牙者，取京丹一斤入汞，四两寿州瓷，碗中唯火急鼓之，成汁如镜，即下碗玲凝如黄金之色，打破状如马牙，用亦如金花。 余说多误也。 其郁花牙须入铅砂中。 炼金九转者，炒铅为砂，鼓砂为铅，如此九转，名曰九铅之法，未能具陈。 玄含者，玄是汞，含为铅花，花为黄牙，故日玄含黄牙。 被褐怀玉，外为狂夫。 言铅外黑带黄，故如被褐。 怀玉者，内白。 如狂夫者，铅白如玉，如狂夫被褐，故日狂夫也。 金为水母，母藏#83子胎。 金者银，水者铅。 铅中有银，以为铅母； 铅是银子，故藏子胎。 水者金子，子藏母胞。 母是银，水是铅，银为子，故居藏母胎胞。 故知其银是七宝之良媒，阴阳之骨髓。 经云：莫败我铅，废我命金。 莫破我车，废我还家。 又云：若铅不真，使汞难亲。 其铅若实，不失家臣。 青腰使者，赤血将军。 和合两姓，异族同群。 所以大丹非铅不成。 夫用铅须得错铅咸。 白腻者，即出得花牙。 杯了者，青淡元花也。 玄铅青腰者，曾青也。 赤血将军者，雄黄也。 二家一是汞，一金花也。 周易参同契注卷上竟 #1因未得其他版本以参校，故暂以俞瑛《周易参同契发挥》四库本（后文简称《发挥》本）校勘其经文。 #2『白』，原作『日』，据其文义改。 #3『配以』，原作『以配』，据上文义例乙正。 #4『者』，据《发挥》本补。 #5『四卦为之』，《发挥》本『四卦』是与上句『牝牡』相连，『为之』作『以为』。

Water is the pivot of the Dao, and its number is named One. As lead and mercury both belong to the northern Water phase, the number of Water is One—this means Heavenly One generates Water. Moreover, the Dao generates the One, and the One is the beginning of the Five Phases, the pivot and mechanism of the Dao. Thus, one catty each of lead and mercury is used. According to this scripture, using one catty of mercury accords with Heaven’s measure and the numbers of the *Book of Changes*; this is the Yin Prime Elixir, with one catty as one dose. If one catty of cinnabar is used, with yellow lead as the covering base, it is called the Yang Prime Elixir. For an elixir of pure Yang transformation, yellow sprout is used. Otherwise, one *liang* of golden blossom serves as the foundation, added month by month, totaling thirty catties after nine months—this is also called the Special Nine Cycles Method. Thus, the methods of Returning Elixir number several schools; though their transformations differ, their crafting follows the same principle. Those who grasp the reason, all produce the Great Elixir. Yet only when fire is mastered does it become the supreme immortal medicine.

At the beginning of Yin and Yang, the Mysterious contains the yellow sprout. As lead belongs to Water, it is called "Mysterious." Within raw lead lies the yellow sprout, resembling gold in form—hence the name "yellow sprout." Lead is the master of the Five Metals and the northern River Chariot. Thus, lead is black on the outside but harbors golden blossom within. Yin is Metal Elder, and Yang is mercury. The Five Metals refer to lead, also called Metal Elder. Metal Elder is another name for lead. Since lead contains the five colors within, it produces five-colored gold—hence the name "Five Metals." It governs mercury, belongs to Water, and can carry the elixir boat. Like a chariot, it is called the River Chariot. As it holds gold within, it harbors the golden blossom. When transformed by yellow lead, it congeals like a mirror, and when struck, resembles horse’s teeth—thus called yellow sprout. If one values the yellow sprout, one must first refine raw lead to obtain its golden blossom and yellow sprout, though both emerge from lead, their crafting differs.

For golden blossom: take nine-cycled lead, remove impurities, and refine it until it resembles a mirror. For one catty of lead, add four *liang* of mercury—some say two *liang*. The teachings vary: some advocate equal parts, others a four-six ratio. Most are incorrect; only three or four parts are precious. Thus, the ancients kept this secret: when adding mercury, swiftly apply fire for half a day, and the golden blossom will emerge like mica, displaying the five colors of mysterious yellow. Use an iron ladle to gather it. If the golden blossom’s color remains unchanged like gold, it is mercury blossom. If, after congealing, its color shifts to greenish, the green is lead blossom. Such blossom is unfit, and no blossom will emerge. Where there is mercury, there is blossom; when the blossom is exhausted, add more mercury until sufficient, then stop. Some say nine-cycled lead is unnecessary—this is mostly incorrect. Otherwise, at least three cycles are needed to produce blossom.

According to this *Contract*, take one catty of blossom, melt it into liquid, add one catty of mercury to congeal it, then grind it into powder and place it in the crucible. For a pure Yang elixir, mix the blossom with lead sand and seal it for one hundred days until the blossom turns red and brown. For one *liang* of blossom, add one *liang* of raw mercury, grind them into powder, and place in the crucible. The sealed blossom is called Autumn Stone or Standing Control Stone. If crafting the Special Method, apply the blossom to coat the crucible and add raw mercury without limit—this too can form the elixir. For yellow sprout: take one catty of capital lead, add four *liang* of mercury, and place in a Shouzhou porcelain bowl. Apply intense fire to melt it into a mirror-like liquid, then cool the bowl until it congeals into a golden color, resembling horse’s teeth when struck. Its use is like that of golden blossom. Other teachings are mostly erroneous. The sealed blossom and sprout must be placed in lead sand.

The method of refining gold through nine cycles involves frying lead into sand and smelting sand back into lead—repeating this nine times is called the Nine Lead Method, which cannot be fully expounded here.

"Mysterious containing" refers to mercury as the Mysterious, and the lead blossom as the contained. The blossom is the yellow sprout—hence "Mysterious containing yellow sprout." "Clad in coarse cloth yet harboring jade" describes one who appears as a madman. Lead’s exterior is black with a yellow hue, like coarse cloth. "Harboring jade" refers to its inner whiteness. Like a madman clad in coarse cloth, lead’s whiteness resembles jade—hence the "madman."

Gold is the mother of Water, and the mother conceals the child’s embryo. Gold here is silver, and Water is lead. Lead contains silver, making it the mother of lead; lead is the child of silver, thus concealing the child’s embryo. Water is the child of gold, and the child resides in the mother’s womb. The mother is silver, and Water is lead; silver is the child, thus dwelling in the mother’s womb. Therefore, silver is the fine matchmaker of the Seven Treasures and the marrow of Yin and Yang.

The scripture states: "Do not ruin my lead, nor abandon my life-metal. Do not break my chariot, nor forsake my return home." It also says: "If the lead is not true, mercury will be hard to befriend. If the lead is genuine, the household retainer will not be lost." The Green-Waisted Envoy and the Red-Blood General unite the two families, gathering different clans into one flock. Thus, the Great Elixir cannot be formed without lead.

When using lead, one must obtain refined, salty lead. If it is white and greasy, it can yield blossom and sprout. If it is spent, it will be pale and yield no blossom. "Mysterious lead with a green waist" refers to malachite. The "Red-Blood General" is realgar. One is mercury, the other is golden blossom. *Commentary on the Zhouyi Cantong Qi*, Volume One, concludes.

chunks.original_text: 真人至妙，若有若元。 无是阳铅也，有是阴汞也。 又银属阳宝，真人是太上宝人，知铅中有宝，化汞为丹者矣。 髻霏大渊，乍沈乍浮。 进而#1分布，各守境隅。 大渊者，是烊铅成汁，投汞入铅汁，汞入铅中。 乍沈乍浮，是作金花法，其汞入铅汁之中，分布铅内，所以被铅所守，不得飞出境隅，故知合丹先炼铅作花伏汞。 又一解大渊者，是灰池杯铅取银。 故经云：灰池炎灼，铅沈银浮。 洁白见宝，可造黄。 金。 二义俱通。 采之类白，造之则朱。 铅为#2表卫，帛裹#3贞居。 言烊铅成汁而白，入汞造作，色变如朱。 铅为表上卫如帛，炼汞入内被裹漠之不得飞，故贞正而居，从白守黑。 至此论造花牙，此后别陈入鼎。 方圆径寸，混而相扶。 先天地生。 生，混杂也。 谓汞入铅华中混杂相扶，后入玄白金华鼎中。 汞是金体，方圆一寸，计重一斤，《契》中所用一斤也。 先，作鼎也。 上盖为天，下盖为地，故天地既立，万物生焉。 宇宙之问，莫非天地所养，故道生天地。 丹是於道，故须天地所养，所以先论鼎器而养成大丹也。 巍巍尊高。 言鼎在太一炉中、三台之上独尊，而故巍巍焉。 所以道德尊高，巍巍焉然，故丹道至尊而高者也。 傍有#4垣阙， 垣墙，是太一炉也。 言炉四面#5而开八门，而通八风。 安十二突象十二时，窟象十二辰，乃有四层而应四时，故云垣阙者也。 状似蓬壶。 壶，鼎也。 亦似投壶，瓶准如鼎，有数种。 样似瓜形，亦得方作，亦得边，皆有取耳。 着小长镍子用时，时蘸水及秤。 若伏火为黄白，即作银壶。 芦子径二寸，长一寸半，受一斤汞。 蓬是炉。 炉按五岳，似蓬莱山。 环匝#6关闭，四通踟跚。 环匝者，鼎四耳，或二耳。 下关关之汞，居内踟跚不出。 守御密固#7 固是固际，守御是看火。 昼不得怠慢，失固际最是急事。 固若不牢密，药即走失尽。 假在固密，精华若元，只有铅丹在耳。 若银壶子不谨密，唯丹在，汞走尽。 经云：六一者，以六及一为七合，固际如漆物，非乎七种泥。 若八石、四神、金英、玉粉等。 丹即誉石粉、赤石脂二味为上下，可使灰盐也。 着此丹，唯在金花、黄牙。 不者，铅、砂皆细研和酝如泥，用之上与盐灰。 若银壶芦子，即用大鹏砂和瑜银末等，输下钢砂。 余说云：不灰、木、戎、盐等。 非也
chunks.translated_text:
The Perfected One attains the utmost subtlety, now present, now absent. The absence is yang lead; the presence is yin mercury. Moreover, silver pertains to the yang treasure, while the Perfected One is the Supreme Treasure Person. Knowing that within lead lies the treasure, one transforms mercury into the elixir.

The great abyss billows in mist, now sinking, now floating. Advancing, it #1 spreads and disperses, each guarding its own boundary. The great abyss refers to molten lead turned to liquid, into which mercury is cast. Now sinking, now floating—this is the method of forming golden flowers: mercury enters the lead liquid, dispersing within the lead, thus bound by the lead and unable to escape its confines. Hence, one knows that to compound the elixir, one must first refine lead into flowers to subdue mercury.

Another interpretation of the great abyss refers to the ash pool where lead yields silver. Thus, the scripture states: "In the ash pool, with blazing heat, lead sinks and silver floats. Pure white, the treasure appears, capable of forging yellow gold." Both meanings are valid.

Gathered, it resembles white; wrought, it turns vermilion. Lead serves as #2 the outer guard, silk enveloping #3 the steadfast core. This speaks of molten lead, white in its liquid state, which, when mercury is introduced and worked, changes color to crimson. Lead acts as the outer guard like silk, enclosing the refined mercury within, preventing its flight. Thus, it remains steadfast and abides, white guarding black.

Here concludes the discussion of forming flower buds; what follows concerns the entry into the crucible.

Round or square, a *cun* in diameter, they merge and support one another. Born before Heaven and Earth. *Born* here means intermingled. It refers to mercury entering the lead flowers, blending and supporting one another, later to be placed within the Mysterious White Metal Flower Crucible. Mercury is the essence of metal, one *cun* in diameter and round, weighing one *jin*—the measure used in the *Cantong Qi*. *Before* refers to the crucible. The upper lid is Heaven; the lower lid, Earth. Thus, once Heaven and Earth are established, the myriad things are born. Within the cosmos, nothing exists that is not nurtured by Heaven and Earth. The Dao gives birth to Heaven and Earth, and the elixir belongs to the Dao. Therefore, it must be nurtured by Heaven and Earth, which is why the crucible is discussed first to cultivate the great elixir.

Lofty and revered. The crucible rests within the Supreme One’s furnace, atop the Three Terraces, uniquely exalted—thus, lofty and revered. The virtue of the Dao is likewise exalted and revered, hence the elixir’s path is supremely noble and high.

Surrounding it are #4 walls and gates. The walls are the Supreme One’s furnace. The furnace has four sides, #5 each opening into eight gates to channel the eight winds. It holds twelve protrusions symbolizing the twelve hours, twelve cavities symbolizing the twelve earthly branches, and four tiers corresponding to the four seasons—hence, walls and gates.

Its form resembles Penglai’s gourd. The *gourd* is the crucible, also akin to a *touhu* vase, shaped like a crucible in various styles. Some resemble melons, others are square or edged, each with its purpose. A small, elongated handle is used for dipping water and weighing. If refining fire for yellow and white, a silver crucible is employed. The reed tube is two *cun* in diameter, one and a half *cun* long, holding one *jin* of mercury. *Penglai* refers to the furnace, modeled after the Five Peaks, resembling Mount Penglai.

Encircling it, #6 sealed and bound, the four passages are secured. *Encircling* refers to the crucible’s four—or two—handles. The lower seal confines the mercury within, preventing its escape. Guarding it, tightly sealed. #7 *Sealed* refers to the sealed boundary; *guarding* refers to tending the fire. One must not slacken by day, for a breach in the seal is most urgent. If the seal is not firm and tight, the medicine will entirely escape. If the seal is secure and dense, only the essence remains, leaving only lead elixir. If the silver crucible is not carefully sealed, only the elixir remains while the mercury flees entirely.

The scripture states: "Six-and-one" refers to six parts to one, making seven measures, the sealed boundary like lacquer, not the seven kinds of clay. Such as the eight stones, four spirits, golden blossom, jade powder, and the like. For the elixir, *yushi* powder and *chishizhi* are used for the upper and lower layers, with ash salt. For this elixir, only golden flowers and yellow buds suffice. Otherwise, lead and cinnabar are finely ground and fermented like mud, applied atop salt ash. For silver crucibles and reed tubes, use *dapeng* cinnabar mixed with refined silver powder and steel sand. Other texts mention non-ash, wood, *rong* salt, and the like—these are incorrect.

chunks.original_text: 关绝奸邪。 谓固际牢密，即无败亏。 邪，飞失也。 曲阁相通#8，以戒不虞。 虞，失也。 言作雄雌，犬牙相合。 外着象鼻。 殷动深嘱，务在牢密。 可以元思，难以愁劳。 神气满堂#9，莫之能留。 守之者昌，失之者亡。 神气者，火也。 堂者，炉也。 满者，武火盛满也。 其火若盛，汞力难当，滑利莫过於汞，去之元踪，寻之元所，故须牢固际若密。 鼎元穿穴损坏，得四时火性，文武应期，所以元诸多思。 在即昌盛，成即为丹，失即消亡。 几欲飞炼，先炼鼎器，后明固际，火气均调，勤心不怠，岂有损败也。 动静休息，常与人俱。 言反覆鼎器及运火，常须三人看守，故阳动阴静，或进退不得离炉，思有动乃元休息，故常与人俱。 是非历藏法，内视有所思。 历，遍也。 言运火动气，皆历星宿藏法得所。 又其室内须得清净，烧辟鬼，九炉画，五岳真形，八方真文，天童玉女，八公九真，十二神王，三大将军步虚坛八方悬镜，四面卓刀烧香，清净洁戒，及精思常存太上、九真八圣、玉女仙童、天兵力士。 左右龙虎，前后朱雀、玄武，在一室之内。 若得其丹妙理，不能绘画形象。 有置太一炉，但清净思存众圣，随事炉电亦得。 履行步斗宿#10， 言房内坛中初发火，及雷雨恶风等，皆须禹步。 步斗星，三步九迹。 六甲次日辰。 运大皆依十二辰次第，而转； 历六十甲子。 从先天至此，论鼎及固际运火作法，此再三深属者，又令人细心也。 但初文后武，渐渐养火，即得不失。 阴道厌一九，浊乱弄元胞。 阴道者，阴元法也。 一是铅精，属北方坎水，水数一。 九者，汞也。 汞为朱砂生，属於南方离，火数九。 以烊铅精为水，投入炼汞相和，得乱汞压在铅，铅乃蔽其汞，在铅内如子居胎，不得飞遁，被铅胞包裹，或上或下，故云弄胞也。 食气呜肠胃，吐正吸所邪#11。 邪是铅，正是汞，气是火。 言汞得火气相食乃成一体。 故龙吐虎吸，言龙虎呼吸也。 汞於铅内，故头呜肠胃。 日满已后，其汞吐出铅上，状如朱砂，其色红紫，名日正阳丹也。 俗喻人服气，吐死纳生也。 昼夜不卧寐，阳明#12未常休。 阳明，火也。 言一年之内，上至三年，朝夜火不得休息。 俗喻朝夜服气，元有休息。 身体以疲倦#13，恍惚状若痴。 言汞在铅花汁中，以经昼夜火稍，恍惚状若痴。 伏亦喻人侍其炉火，日夜不休，以至痕倦，神情恍惚如痴。 又作丹及黄白，皆先责汞结为砂，若丹用三年左味以入金花和支，亦入银器中支，续续向四边刮取乾汞，若黄白以对半入母同支汞以成砂，如石将砂入器中。 一百二十日伏火为宝，以充用不堪为药，为有金铅故也。 若作九转丹，支汞为砂，梼碎入鼎，五符覆藉。 若此经正议如前。 金汞入鼎，俗喻服气休根，精神恍惚，身体痴倦矣。 百脉鼎沸驰，不得清澄居。 言汞居铅内，在鼎中被火迫，常漫涌沸，汞驰入铅，百脉中不得清澄居。 而俗喻从服食其气，咽元至此气，至丹田满，其百豚常若雷鸣，亦如沸汤，至久亦不得长生。 虚动疲倦，不得丹服。 神若如痴，终元长生之理也。 累土立坛宇，朝暮敬祭祀。 言丹院内立坛，朝暮祭祀。 俗喻人求道立坛，对祭勤苦，亦不能得道。 鬼物见形象，梦寐感慨之。
chunks.translated_text:
Seal against deceit and deviation. This means the sealed boundary must be firm and tight, so there shall be no loss or deficiency. "Deviation" refers to flying away and loss. The winding chambers connect in sequence, to guard against the unforeseen. "Unforeseen" means loss. It speaks of interlocking male and female parts, fitting together like dog’s teeth. Externally, an elephant’s trunk is applied. Stir deeply and exhort earnestly—firmness and tightness are paramount. This may be contemplated with profound thought, but not with anxious toil.

When the *qi* of spirit fills the chamber, none can retain it. Those who preserve it prosper; those who lose it perish. "Spirit *qi*" is fire. "Chamber" is the furnace. "Fills" means the martial fire is abundant. If the fire is too strong, the mercury’s power cannot withstand it. Nothing is more slippery and swift than mercury—once gone, it leaves no trace, and no place can be found to seek it. Thus, the boundary must be as firm and tight as lacquer.

If the crucible is pierced or damaged, one must grasp the fire’s nature across the four seasons, balancing civil and martial fires in due time—this is why profound contemplation is unnecessary. When present, it flourishes; when perfected, it becomes the elixir; when lost, it vanishes. Before attempting to refine and sublimate, first refine the crucible and vessel, then ensure the sealed boundary is secure. When fire and *qi* are harmonized, and one’s diligence is unwavering, how could there be loss or failure?

Movement and stillness, rest and activity—these ever accompany the practitioner. This speaks of repeatedly handling the crucible and managing the fire, which must always be overseen by three people. Thus, when yang moves and yin is still, or when advancing and retreating, one must not leave the furnace. Even when movement occurs, there is no true rest—hence, it ever accompanies the practitioner.

This is not the method of traversing the hidden treasuries; it is inner contemplation with focused thought. "Traversing" means to pass through. It speaks of managing the fire and moving *qi*, all in accordance with the methods of the stellar lodges and hidden treasuries. Moreover, the chamber must be purified: expel ghosts by burning, inscribe the nine furnaces, draw the true forms of the Five Peaks, the true scripts of the eight directions, the Jade Maidens and Heavenly Lads, the Eight Lords and Nine Perfected, the Twelve Divine Kings, and the Three Great Generals. Step the void altar in the eight directions, hang mirrors on all sides, plant swords at the four quarters, burn incense, and maintain purity and precepts. Concentrate the mind to constantly visualize the Most High, the Nine Perfected, Eight Sages, Jade Maidens, Immortal Lads, Heavenly Soldiers, and Mighty Warriors. To the left and right, the Green Dragon and White Tiger; before and behind, the Vermilion Bird and Dark Warrior—all within a single chamber.

If one grasps the wondrous principle of the elixir, one need not draw these images. Some set up a Supreme Unity furnace, merely purifying the mind and visualizing the host of sages—this too suffices for the furnace’s work.

Tread the steps of the Dipper’s lodges. This means that when first igniting the fire in the altar chamber, or when thunder, rain, evil winds, and the like arise, one must perform the Yu Step. Step the stars of the Dipper—three steps, nine traces. The six jia days follow the sequence of days and hours. All major operations follow the twelve earthly branches in order, cycling through the sixty jia-zi. From the primordial to this point, the discussion of crucibles, sealed boundaries, fire management, and methods of operation is reiterated thrice—this is to urge the practitioner to be meticulous.

At first, the method is civil; later, martial—gradually nurturing the fire ensures nothing is lost. The Way of yin suppresses one and nine, its turbid chaos playing with the primordial womb. "The Way of yin" refers to the yin primordial method. "One" is the essence of lead, belonging to the northern Kan water, whose number is one. "Nine" is mercury. Mercury is born of cinnabar, belonging to the southern Li fire, whose number is nine. Melt the essence of lead into water, then cast it into the refined mercury to blend them. The chaotic mercury is pressed into the lead, which then conceals the mercury within itself, like a child dwelling in the womb, unable to flee. Enveloped by the lead’s womb, it moves up and down—hence, it is said to "play with the womb."

Consuming *qi*, the intestines and stomach resound; exhaling the true, inhaling the deviant. "Deviant" is lead; "true" is mercury; "*qi*" is fire. It speaks of mercury uniting with fire *qi* to become one body. Thus, the dragon exhales and the tiger inhales—this refers to the breathing of dragon and tiger. Mercury within lead causes the head to resound in the intestines and stomach. After the sun is full, the mercury is exhaled onto the lead, taking the form of cinnabar, its color crimson-purple—this is called the True Yang Elixir. The common analogy is that one exhales the dead and inhales the living.

Day and night, one does not sleep; the yang brightness never rests. "Yang brightness" is fire. It speaks of the fire within a year, extending up to three years, never ceasing day or night. The common analogy is that one practices *qi*-absorption day and night without rest.

The body grows weary, the spirit dazed, as if in a stupor. It speaks of mercury within the lead’s blossoming sap, subjected to day and night of fire—its state is dazed, as if in a stupor. It also analogizes the practitioner tending the furnace fire day and night without rest, becoming exhausted, the spirit and emotions dazed as if in a stupor.

Furthermore, in making the elixir or yellow and white, one must first refine mercury into cinnabar. For the elixir, use three years of left-flavored [mercury] mixed with golden blossoms and branches, also placed in silver vessels to branch. Continuously scrape the dry mercury from the four sides. For yellow and white, use equal parts mother [lead] to branch the mercury into cinnabar, like stone. Place the cinnabar in the vessel, subdue the fire for one hundred twenty days to make a treasure. If unfit for use as medicine, it is because of the presence of metallic lead.

For the nine-cycle elixir, branch the mercury into cinnabar, grind it finely, place it in the crucible, and cover it with the Five Talismans. The correct discussion of this scripture is as above. When gold and mercury enter the crucible, the common analogy is that absorbing *qi* severs the root—spirit and essence grow dazed, the body weary and stuporous.

The hundred vessels boil and surge, unable to settle in clarity. It speaks of mercury within lead, in the crucible under fire’s pressure, constantly surging and boiling. The mercury rushes into the lead, unable to settle in clarity within the hundred vessels. The common analogy is that from consuming *qi* to this point, when *qi* reaches the cinnabar field and fills it, the hundred vessels constantly roar like thunder, like boiling water—yet even after a long time, one cannot attain longevity.

Vain movement and weariness prevent the elixir from being ingested. If the spirit is as if in a stupor, there is ultimately no principle of eternal life.

Pile earth to erect an altar, morning and evening offer reverent sacrifices. It speaks of erecting an altar within the elixir courtyard, offering sacrifices morning and evening. The common analogy is that one seeking the Dao erects an altar, toiling diligently in sacrifice—yet still cannot attain the Dao.

Ghostly beings manifest forms, dreams and sleep stir emotions.

chunks.original_text: 言衍士恭勤炉火，常以精心，得鬼神见护，夜梦神感教汞也。 亦喻人立坛祭祀，感得鬼见梦通，谓言得道也。 心欢意喜悦#14，自为#15必延期。 期，寿年也。 为心身动苦得神助，心意喜悦。 神丹一成，服铃延年不死。 俗喻感得鬼见梦佑通，心将喜悦，言得长生。 遽以夭命死，腐露其形骸。 言汞一年伏火已后吐出铅上，伏死成丹，名日正阳之丹。 故日伏火腐露其形也。 经云：十月脱出其胞。 是汞火足，脱出铅上也。 俗喻人求道服气，休敉立坛勤祭，感梦神现，心怀其喜意，谓得长生之道。 如此之辈，不免其死。 不得大丹服之，终不免腐露而死者也。
chunks.translated_text:
The adept diligently tends the furnace flame, ever with concentrated mind, and so gains the protection of spirits and gods, who in nightly dreams divinely instruct the mercury. The common analogy is that one who erects an altar and offers sacrifices may likewise be moved by spirits appearing in dreams—yet this is called attaining the Dao.

Heart gladdened, will rejoicing, one deems it certain to prolong the term. *Term* here means the span of years. For the toil of body and mind gains the aid of spirits, and the heart’s intent rejoices. Once the divine elixir is formed, its ingestion surely extends years without death. The common analogy is that one moved by spirits appearing in dreams feels joy in the heart and speaks of attaining longevity. Yet suddenly the mandate of heaven is cut short, and the body decays, exposed to the elements.

It speaks of mercury, after a year of subduing fire, disgorging lead above, subdued and dead to form the elixir—called the elixir of True Yang. Thus it is said: subduing fire exposes the form to decay. The scripture states: “In the tenth month, it sheds its womb.” This is mercury, its fire complete, shedding above the lead. The common analogy is that one who seeks the Dao, ingesting *qi*, resting and toiling, erecting altars and offering diligent sacrifices, moved by dreams of spirits manifesting, cherishes joy in the heart and deems it the Way of longevity. Yet such as these cannot escape death. Without ingesting the great elixir, in the end they cannot avoid decay and exposure in death.

chunks.original_text: 举错辄有为#16，悖逆失枢机。 言伏汞为丹，悖不得理，辄自气意心赢，逆失枢机之秘法。 若求法不明，费火丧财，遽失生路而夭其命。 假得丹成，不晓出毒，辄为便服，为毒所中，亦丧其命。 喻如人不得其丹理； 徒费其功，服气立坛，终不免死，失其机要也。 诸卫甚众多，千有万余言#17。 言飞丹炼石千万余方，大丹之秘不过一二。 具此《参同契》经内，亦说三二之法，但明其金石阴阳药性，但得汞伏火成丹紫色，即是大还丹药。 任诸方所说，终不离铅汞。 但学炼铅精，妙即是伏得汞也。 元其种类，万元成日，乃妙者要务在由人制作。 故知学道须广集经方，莫耻下问，道元不成也。 若恃心高自执一理，叉不能成，成亦不妙。 所以，其丹不出铅汞也。 古歌日：白汞生朱砂，黑汞化黄丹。 其中数九九，变化五三般。 若至紫河车，黄金元处安。 故知大丹不离铅汞，只是变化由人，且大丹若化得五金入汞成宝，始是大还丹也。 罕见今人学得一法，制汞始至伏火即云大还丹。 上更元法，甚愚甚愚。 夫大丹，但莫着金银、石药等所杂，即是上元毒神丹。 若杂诸石，只可治病，有毒损人，但调得铅汞，即是长生神丹也。 又见愚人只得调铅制汞之法，云炒铅九转为丹，烧汞七返为朱，相和入鼎，雄雌所制，誉石固际，或黄丹荡治，亦有取银为末，用金为泥，将和雄雌曾等，飞炼入瓶。 一年之火伏养，及其年毕，元有半成，唯有金银铅在，余尽为灰，灵汞独飞，更元一分。 愚瞽之士云：是神丹服后不调，体沈腰重，忽有毒发，便当伤逝。 即云犯触被神惩罚。 据此不知药性，何大之甚？ 故人命至重，一死更元再生，服毒乃在其身，仙路如何可望。 但明铅汞为丹，虽未至精，但得伏火，即是长生之药。 虽知用铅仍不得，铅居汞内须去，铅尽然可服之。 故暂借铅为根，岂应堪服？ 故知其法甚多，须广商量，不可造次，得一小法即将世法，言元过此法，乃非也。 前却违黄老，曲折戾九都。 夫飞丹炼石，起自黄老，次太上老君。 九转者，是仙官调服丹学道之士名。 戾九都者，仙官又是九教丹经，是老君度关授与尹喜说三化五转、九还七返之法及诸丹卫。 非其一二，或前或后，不依科禁，故云前却曲折经法矣。 明者省厥旨，旷然知所由。 令学丹卫之士旷然明其法。 多集仙经，自悟其理，故知其所由也。 勤而从之#18，夙夜不息#19。 经营#20三载，轻举远游。 跨火不燃，入水不濡。 能存能亡，长乐元忧。 道成德就，潜伏俟时。 言好道之人，勤求丹衍，供侍炉火，朝夕不休，不敢怠堕，乃经三载得丹，成后服之得仙，道成德就。 水火不害，坐在立亡，千变万化，役使鬼神，寿同天地，长乐何忧，潜遁人问，待时而仙也。 太一乃召，移居中洲。 太一是仙伯，中洲是仙官也。 服丹之后，金骨玉髓，乃非凡体p及行阴德，精思坐忘，赛霞行气，太一使玉童、玉女取召入仙官也。 功次#21上升，应受图录#22。 言服半剂且住人闲，待功满三千，然后服尽一剂升天。 录是仙人戒，图是五岳真形。 图一斤为一剂，大还丹四两为一剂，此应是二斤药也。 《火记》不虚作，演《易》以明之。 火记者，谓大还神丹，象於《周易》，以明其用爻卦转鼎运火，故托於《周易》明迷其妙，而不虚作之也。
chunks.translated_text:
Every action taken is an endeavor, yet perversion and rebellion lose the pivotal mechanism. It speaks of subduing mercury to form the elixir—if perverse and not attaining principle, one’s *qi*, intent, and heart become depleted, rebelling and losing the secret method of the pivotal mechanism. Should one seek the method without clarity, one wastes fire and squanders wealth, suddenly losing the path of life and cutting short one’s mandate. Even if the elixir is obtained but its toxins are not understood, hasty ingestion leads to poisoning and the loss of life. This is like those who fail to grasp the principle of the elixir: they waste their efforts in vain, ingesting *qi* and erecting altars, yet in the end cannot escape death, losing the essential mechanism.

The methods are exceedingly numerous, numbering in the thousands and tens of thousands. It speaks of flying elixirs and alchemical stones in myriad formulas, yet the secrets of the great elixir are no more than one or two. These are contained within the *Cantong Qi*, which also expounds two or three methods, clarifying only the yin-yang properties of metals and stones. When mercury is subdued by fire and the elixir turns purple, this is the great returning elixir. No matter what the various formulas claim, they ultimately do not depart from lead and mercury. Simply learning to refine lead essence—when mastered—is to subdue mercury. In their original kind, they are not inherently completed; the wonder lies in human craftsmanship. Thus, those who study the Dao must broadly collect scriptures and formulas, never ashamed to seek guidance from inferiors, for the Dao will not be achieved otherwise. If one clings to arrogance and insists on a single principle, one cannot succeed—or if one does, it will not be wondrous. Therefore, the elixir does not depart from lead and mercury.

An ancient song says:
White mercury begets cinnabar,
Black mercury transforms into yellow elixir.
Within it, the numbers nine by nine,
Five and three transformations unfold.
When it reaches the purple river chariot,
Yellow gold finds no place to rest.

Thus, the great elixir does not depart from lead and mercury; it is merely a matter of transformation by human hands. Moreover, if the great elixir can transmute the five metals into mercury to form treasure, only then is it the great returning elixir. Yet it is rare to see one today who, having learned a single method and subdued mercury to the point of fire, claims it as the great returning elixir—without further methods, how foolish, how foolish!

The great elixir must not be adulterated with gold, silver, or mineral drugs, for then it becomes the supreme poisonous divine elixir. If mixed with various stones, it can only treat illness, yet its toxins harm the body. Only by harmonizing lead and mercury is it the elixir of longevity. Yet I have seen fools who, having learned only the method of harmonizing lead and subduing mercury, claim that frying lead nine times makes the elixir, or burning mercury seven times makes cinnabar. They mix them in the crucible, regulating the male and female, praising the solidity of the stone, or refining yellow elixir, sometimes even taking silver as powder and using gold as mud, blending them with equal parts of male and female, flying and refining them in a bottle. After a year of fire and nurturing, when the time is complete, not even half is achieved—only gold, silver, and lead remain, the rest turned to ash, the numinous mercury having flown away entirely. Such blind fools claim it is a divine elixir, yet after ingestion, the body grows heavy and the waist sinks, toxins suddenly erupting, leading to injury and death. They say this is divine punishment for transgression. How profoundly ignorant of the properties of the medicine! Human life is most precious; once dead, there is no rebirth. To ingest poison is to harm the body—how can the path to immortality be hoped for?

Yet if one understands that lead and mercury form the elixir—even if not yet refined—merely subduing them by fire makes the medicine of longevity. Even if one knows to use lead, if it is not properly obtained, and the lead within mercury is not removed, the lead remains and can be ingested. Thus, lead is but temporarily borrowed as a root—how could it be fit for consumption? Therefore, though the methods are many, one must broadly deliberate and not act hastily. To obtain a minor method and then claim it surpasses all others is incorrect.

To go against the Yellow and the Old, twisting and turning against the Nine Capitals—flying elixirs and alchemical stones originated with the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, then with the Most High Lord Lao. The "nine transformations" refer to the names of Daoist adepts who study and ingest the elixir. The "Nine Capitals" are the nine teachings of the elixir scriptures, which Lord Lao transmitted at the pass to Yin Xi, expounding the methods of three transformations, five cycles, nine returns, and seven reversions, along with various elixir methods. Not limited to one or two, whether before or after, if one does not follow the regulations, it is said to go against and twist the scriptural methods.

The enlightened comprehend its meaning, clearly knowing the path. Let those who study elixir methods be enlightened and understand the method. By collecting many immortal scriptures, they awaken to the principle and thus know the path.

Diligently follow it, day and night without rest. After three years of endeavor, one ascends lightly and travels afar. Unburned by fire, undrenched by water. Able to appear and disappear, ever joyful without sorrow. The Dao is achieved, virtue is perfected, one conceals oneself and awaits the time. It speaks of those who love the Dao, diligently seeking elixir methods, tending the furnace fire day and night without laziness. After three years, the elixir is obtained, and upon ingestion, one attains immortality—Dao achieved, virtue perfected. Unharmed by water or fire, able to sit or stand at will, with a thousand transformations and ten thousand changes, commanding ghosts and spirits, lifespan equal to heaven and earth, ever joyful without sorrow. One withdraws from the mortal world, awaiting the time to ascend.

The Great One summons, moving residence to the Central Continent. The Great One is the immortal lord; the Central Continent is the immortal palace. After ingesting the elixir, with golden bones and jade marrow, one is no longer a mortal body. By practicing hidden virtue, meditating in stillness, cutting off thoughts, refining *qi*, and riding the clouds, the Great One sends jade lads and jade maidens to summon one into the immortal palace.

As one’s merit accumulates, one ascends, receiving charts and records. It speaks of ingesting half a dose and remaining among mortals, awaiting the fulfillment of three thousand merits before consuming the full dose to ascend to heaven. The "records" are the precepts of immortals; the "charts" are the true forms of the Five Peaks. One *jin* of the chart is one dose; four *liang* of the great returning elixir is one dose—this refers to two *jin* of medicine.

The *Fire Record* is not falsely composed, expounding the *Yi* to clarify it. The *Fire Record* refers to the great returning divine elixir, which takes the *Zhou Yi* as its model to clarify the use of hexagrams and trigrams, the turning of the crucible, and the movement of fire. Thus, it relies on the *Zhou Yi* to illuminate its wonders, and it is not falsely composed.
chunks.overlap_context: cay. The scripture states: “In the tenth month, it sheds its womb.” This is mercury, its fire complete, shedding above the lead. The common analogy is that one who seeks the Dao, ingesting *qi*, resting and toiling, erecting altars and offering diligent sacrifices, moved by dreams of spirits manifesting, cherishes joy in the heart and deems it the Way of longevity. Yet such as these cannot escape death. Without ingesting the great elixir, in the end they cannot avoid decay and exposure in death.
